"originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 187, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8185975071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:31:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:31:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:30:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/mlb/rickwood-field-mlb-cardinals-giants/article_2c6a58dc-d7ce-54c9-8b11-cbb90fb6512d.html", "title": "Rickwood Field welcomes Major League Baseball to Birmingham", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- Gerald Watkins watched Aaron Judge, Giancarlo Stanton and other New York Yankees wade through stalks of corn onto an Iowa field in 2021, near the filming site for the 1989 baseball movie \"Field of Dreams.\"\n\nWatkins thought about Rickwood Field, the 114-year-old ballpark in his hometown Birmingham, Alabama, where Willie Mays got his start, and he called Major League Baseball with a pitch.\n\n\"The Field of Dreams is really cool,\" Watkins, 68, said, \"but we have a real Field of Dreams here. This is a place where Willie Mays, among others, was standing in the outfield dreaming about being in the big leagues.\"\n\nNow, the big leagues are coming to Birmingham. Rickwood Field, the oldest professional ballpark in the U.S. and former home to baseball Hall of Famer Mays and the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues, will host an MLB game between the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday.\n\nPeople are also reading... Comedian Pete Davidson shops local ahead of Bloomington shows Rivian announces next set of company-wide layoffs Over 55,000 expected for Tailgate N' Tallboys music fest in Bloomington Bloomington woman in custody on murder charges in rural McLean County shooting Juror dismissed in McLean County murder trial for suspected 'bias' towards defendant First night of Tailgate N' Tallboys canceled due to severe weather Jaylin Bones found guilty in 2022 Bloomington murder Downed power lines and poles cause road closures in McLean County Witness places murder defendant at the scene as Bloomington murder trial continues State: Murder defendant fought Bloomington man over a gun before fatal shooting Videos, phone data show murder defendant's path to Chicago after fatal Bloomington shooting Motorcyclist killed in Tuesday morning crash in Bloomington Ex-Illinois basketball star Terrence Shannon found not guilty in rape trial Michael Mounce survives late push to capture Bloomington-Normal Match Play championship Flick Fact: Today's biggest rip-offs that we all pay?\n\nThe game meant to honor Mays and many other Negro Leaguers will be both somber and reminiscent. Mays, the electrifying center fielder who left an enduring mark on baseball, died Tuesday afternoon, a day after announcing that he wouldn't attend the game in person.\n\n\"All of Major League Baseball is in mourning today as we are gathered at the very ballpark where a career and a legacy like no other began,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise. From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nA landmark of hope\n\nRickwood Field sits just a few miles west of downtown Birmingham -- a rustic and modest green landmark with hints of history layered in its walls.\n\nIt's a time capsule of opportunity and oppression -- a site for social gatherings like women's suffrage rallies and other political events, and host to the best baseball talents of the 20th century. Commercials and baseball films have also been shot there, including parts of the Jackie Robinson biopic \"42.\"\n\nRickwood Field hosted Alabama's first integrated sports team, the minor league Birmingham Barons, in 1964 -- 17 years after Robinson integrated the majors. And it has seen more than 50% of baseball Hall of Famers walk its grounds, from legendary Negro Leaguers like Mays, Josh Gibson and Satchel Paige to MLB greats Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Mickey Mantle.\n\n\"The majors? I didn't dream about the impossible,\" Mays recently told the San Francisco Chronicle. \"I was taught to see your goal in your mind and work toward it. I could work toward getting to Rickwood Field and the Birmingham Black Barons. I didn't need to dream for that. For that, I needed to work hard. So, I did. Rickwood became my training ground.\"\n\nMays became a star there at only 17 years old, helping the Black Barons reach the Negro League World Series in 1948. Major league scouts came to see him play, and the Black Barons were so popular locally that ministers sometimes preached early on Sundays to accommodate fans eager to attend games.\n\n\"Rickwood is special because it's where so many baseball careers began, and it's still standing,\" said Roy Wood Jr., a comedian and actor born in Birmingham. \"When you're there, you can still feel that history. I feel as strongly about Rickwood as someone would (feel) visiting their childhood home as an adult.\"\n\nWood played high school baseball at Rickwood Field in the 1990s. At the time, he said Rickwood was just another place for him to play the sport he loved. That changed when he learned the history.\n\n'A place where horror was allowed to take a pause'\n\nThe 10,800-seat stadium opened in 1910 during a time when baseball was the premier sport in Alabama. With few major league franchises in the South during those days, baseball fans in Alabama clung to minor league teams like the all-white Birmingham Barons, who played at Rickwood from 1910-1961, 1964-65 and 1981-87. Other white stars -- like Hall of Famers Ty Cobb and Honus Wagner -- came through Rickwood for spring exhibitions. Alabama and Auburn both used Rickwood as home fields for their college football teams.\n\nFor Black people, Rickwood and the Negro Leagues were an introduction to Black athletic talent.\n\n\"This league creates common heroes, common teams,\" said Rob Ruck, a historian focusing on Black and Latino roots in sport, \"a national institution that Black Americans rally around, and it gives them a collective self-esteem because of their abilities in sport.\"\n\nThe field was also a bright spot amid the fight for racial equality in the 1950s and 1960s. Alabama, one of the epicenters of the Civil Rights Movement, was the site of marches for voting rights and boycotts, as well as brutal beatings, civil unrest and deadly bombings.\n\n\"It was a place where horror was allowed to take a pause for nine innings,\" Wood said. \" ... Rickwood was never going to solve Black people's problems, but it represented a place where Black people didn't have to think about them for a few hours.\"\n\nMaintaining history\n\nThe ballpark is still standing against many odds. Built around the same time as Pittsburgh's Forbes Field, Philadelphia's Shibe Park, Chicago's Comiskey Park and Detroit's Tiger Stadium, Rickwood has outlasted them all, with high school and college games still being played there.\n\nWatkins and the Friends of Rickwood organization made up of about 30 volunteers have maintained it, along with others like Jabreil Weir, the head groundskeeper in charge of the field's day-to-day upkeep.\n\n\"Who would have thought MLB would come to Birmingham, Alabama?\" Weir said. \"Who ever thought that I would be in the position that I am to be a part of this event? These are moments that you dream of.\"\n\nWeir has worked with MLB in preparing the stadium to host a major league game. Renovations include a new field with lights, upgraded dugouts, a new drainage system and a new backstopping netting system to protect fans during the game, according to Murray Cook, MLB's field and stadium consultant.\n\nOther events have been held this week, including a Double-A game at the ballpark on Tuesday between the Birmingham Barons and Montgomery Biscuits of the Southern League. The game was paused while the PA announcer shared news of Mays' death, and fans reacted by standing, cheering and chanting \"Willie! Willie!\"\n\nThe game is part of an ongoing effort by MLB to highlight and celebrate achievements of Black players -- a push that comes amid criticism for a league where the percentage of Black major leaguers is historically low. MLB's endeavors have also included grassroots programs for underprivileged youth players and the recent integration of Negro Leagues statistics into its official records.\n\n\"This gives us an opportunity to talk about race in the context of sport,\" Ruck said, adding later, \"We've got to talk about race in serious ways, and I think this game, the stats, make that happen.\"\n\nSports Week in Pictures: US Open golf, international soccer and more! {"uri": "8187313551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:37:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:37:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:36:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/sports/mlb-rickwood-field-what-know-about-giants-cardinals-game-historic-landmark", "title": "MLB at Rickwood Field: What to know about Giants-Cardinals game at historic landmark", "body": "Ken Rosenthal and Will Cain preview the Giants-Cardinals game, airing Thursday at 7:15pm ET on FOX.\n\nRickwood Field, the oldest professional ballpark in the United States, will be the host of an MLB game between the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday night.\n\nThe stadium, which opened in 1910, is located in Birmingham, Alabama, and is on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nIt was the host for the Negro Leagues' Birmingham Black Barons, as well as the minor leagues' Birmingham Barons and Birmingham A's. The Philadelphia Phillies and Pittsburgh Pirates used the ballpark as a spring training site in the early 1900s.\n\nBaseball Hall of Famers Ty Cobb and Honus Wagner were among the legends who came through. However, for many, fans got to see the talent of the Negro Leagues, including Willie Mays, who got his start with the Black Barons at the age of 17.\n\nHOW MLB'S RICKWOOD FIELD GAME WILL MAKE HUGE STATEMENT IN COMMUNITY -- AND BASEBALL\n\nMays, who passed away this week at 93, told the San Francisco Chronicle that playing in the majors was not something he thought he could attain - at least not until Jackie Robinson first broke the color barrier in baseball, and Larry Doby followed him in the American League.\n\nMays got his start with the New York Giants in 1951 and was the Rookie of the Year.\n\n\"The majors? I didn't dream about the impossible,\" he told the paper before his death. \"I was taught to see your goal in your mind and work toward it. I could work toward getting to Rickwood Field and the Birmingham Black Barons. I didn't need to dream for that. For that, I needed to work hard. So, I did. Rickwood became my training ground.\"\n\nThursday night's game was set to honor Mays, who before his death announced he could not make the trip to Alabama.\n\n\"All of Major League Baseball is in mourning today as we are gathered at the very ballpark where a career and a legacy like no other began,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise. From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nHOW MLB AT RICKWOOD FIELD WILL 'GIVE THE NEGRO LEAGUES THEIR FLOWERS'\n\nRickwood Field was also noted for its play in American Civil Rights history.\n\nIt was one of the sites of marches for voting rights and boycotts, but on the end, brutal beatings, civil unrest and bombings.\n\n\"It was a place where horror was allowed to take a pause for nine innings,\" comedian Roy Wood Jr. told The Associated Press. \"... Rickwood was never going to solve Black people's problems, but it represented a place where Black people didn't have to think about them for a few hours.\"\n\nRickwood's head groundskeeper, Jabreil Weir, helped MLB get the facility ready to host a game.\n\nSome of the renovations included a new drainage system and backstop netting.\n\n\"Who would have thought MLB would come to Birmingham, Alabama?\" Weir told The Associated Press. \"Who ever thought that I would be in the position that I am to be a part of this event? These are moments that you dream of.\"", "source": {"uri": "foxnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fox News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ryan_gaydos@foxnews.com", "name": "Ryan Gaydos", "type": {"uri": "8187475343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:38:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:38:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:35:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://omaha.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_f71011f6-505f-5b4e-b948-242f48447be2.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@omaha.com", "name": {"uri": "8187488687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:46:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:46:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:45:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_c8eccf52-5e1f-54c9-8264-057ce3fc15ba.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\nLocations Stlouis Be the first to {"uri": "8186502345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:07:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:07:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:07:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/news/rickwood-field-team-birmingham-black-barons/ad3b9466dd9e6198542fcd77", "title": "What team played at Rickwood Field? Revisiting the Birmingham Black Barons from 1920 to 1960", "body": "Rickwood Field is the oldest ballpark in America, so it shouldn't surprise anyone that it has a rich history.\n\nSome of baseball's greatest players have played at the stadium. More top-tier players will be in action there as the Cardinals and Giants play an MLB game at the field.\n\nRickwood no longer has a team that calls it home full-time. The Birmingham Barons -- the White Sox's Double-A affiliate -- now play at Regions Field, though they play the occasional game at Rickwood Field.\n\nBut from 1920 to 1960, Rickwood Field had two full-time teams play within its confines. The Barons were one and the Birmingham Black Barons -- a Negro League team that produced a handful of Hall of Famers -- were the other.\n\nHere's what to know about the Black Barons, as the Giants and MLB honor Willie Mays' first professional club.\n\nMORE: Willie Mays' career, from start with Black Barons to Hall of Fame run with Giants\n\nThe Birmingham Black Barons were one of the primary residents of Rickwood Field during the ballpark's heydey.\n\nThe Black Barons were a Negro League team that began playing in 1920. They played through the 1960 season and won four championships (1943, 1944, 1948 and 1959).\n\nMORE: Revisiting Willie Mays' Hall of Fame stats, accolades\n\nThe Black Barons began as a part of the Southern League, which Hall of Famer Rube Foster organized. The club spent the first 20 years of its history bouncing between the Southern League -- a minor league operation -- and the Negro National and American Leagues, which were at the professional level; this was due to financial issues stemming from The Great Depression, per the Negro Southern League Museum.\n\nAfter not playing during the 1939 season, the Black Barons established themselves as a Negro American League team and competed at that level for the final 20 years of their existence. They won four league titles after moving to that level, with their early success -- pennant wins in 1943 and 1944 -- came after Harlem Globetrotters owner Abe Saperstein purchased the team.\n\nAfter baseball's integration, the Negro Leagues gradually declined, and attendance for the Black Barons thinned. As a result, the team converted into a barnstorming squad and played their final Negro League game in 1960. It is believed their final year sporting the Birmingham nickname came in 1962.\n\nMORE: Why Willie Mays was known as the 'Say Hey Kid'\n\nThe Black Barons saw five Hall of Famers play for them during their history. Willie Mays notably suited up for the squad when he was 17 while Satchel Paige became a dominant pitcher with the Black Barons during the 1927 run to the Negro League World Series.\n\nBelow is a look at the Black Barons to make the Baseball Hall of Fame:\n\nBeyond those Hall of Famers, the Black Barons also had Goose Tatum -- a.k.a. The Clown Prince of Basketball -- on the team. In the team's later years, Charlie Pride was their top player. He eventually became better known as a country singer.\n\nDan Bankhead, the first Black pitcher in MLB, also pitched for Birmingham in four of five seasons from 1940 to 1944.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187514027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:08:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:08:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:06:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_5fd0b6af-01cc-5263-bc25-c302ff149cee.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Owner of Starbeck's Smokehouse opening burger restaurant in Cedar Falls in July College Football: Cedar Falls native, grandson of former Panther basketball assistant coach commits to UNI Cedar Falls man arrested for alleged theft of electric bikes Car trapped under semitruck in collision on North Elk Run Road Two women charged in counterfeiting operation at Evansdale home Angel Reese says Caitlin Clark gets 'special whistle.' It blew after Reese's blow to Clark's head Two transported to hospital Saturday after motorcycle crashed in ditch Greene man airlifted after motorcycle crashes with pickup west of Plainfield UPDATE: Cedar Falls officer thrown from vehicle during traffic stop Nebraska man arrested in Quasqueton cemetery crash Rural mail carrier pleads to theft of home improvement store rebates Several injured in Bremer County crash Waterloo offices closed for Wednesday for Juneteenth; construction at yard waste site Waterloo man arrested after police find gun following traffic stop High court ruling shields city in 'criminal' diving board suit\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.09019607843137245, "wgt": 181, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8185971185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:26:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:26:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:25:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/mlb/rickwood-field-mlb-cardinals-giants/article_9be3ad36-13ff-5500-b67b-2f8c99afd60f.html", "title": "Rickwood Field welcomes Major League Baseball to Birmingham", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- Gerald Watkins watched Aaron Judge, Giancarlo Stanton and other New York Yankees wade through stalks of corn onto an Iowa field in 2021, near the filming site for the 1989 baseball movie \"Field of Dreams.\"\n\nWatkins thought about Rickwood Field, the 114-year-old ballpark in his hometown Birmingham, Alabama, where Willie Mays got his start, and he called Major League Baseball with a pitch.\n\n\"The Field of Dreams is really cool,\" Watkins, 68, said, \"but we have a real Field of Dreams here. This is a place where Willie Mays, among others, was standing in the outfield dreaming about being in the big leagues.\"\n\nNow, the big leagues are coming to Birmingham. Rickwood Field, the oldest professional ballpark in the U.S. and former home to baseball Hall of Famer Mays and the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues, will host an MLB game between the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday.\n\nPeople are also reading... Iowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a homicide' Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Former Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Man dies in standoff with authorities in Sac County Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Athlete of the Week: Miller's motor leading the way for West Monona Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Sioux City man pleads not guilty of manslaughter Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Boat speed rule imposed on Okoboji lakes in wake of heavy rains, storms that also led to wastewater discharges Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Top area softball performers: RSM last unbeaten team; Mentzer, Moreau swinging hot bats\n\nThe game meant to honor Mays and many other Negro Leaguers will be both somber and reminiscent. Mays, the electrifying center fielder who left an enduring mark on baseball, died Tuesday afternoon, a day after announcing that he wouldn't attend the game in person.\n\n\"All of Major League Baseball is in mourning today as we are gathered at the very ballpark where a career and a legacy like no other began,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise. From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nA landmark of hope\n\nRickwood Field sits just a few miles west of downtown Birmingham -- a rustic and modest green landmark with hints of history layered in its walls.\n\nIt's a time capsule of opportunity and oppression -- a site for social gatherings like women's suffrage rallies and other political events, and host to the best baseball talents of the 20th century. Commercials and baseball films have also been shot there, including parts of the Jackie Robinson biopic \"42.\"\n\nRickwood Field hosted Alabama's first integrated sports team, the minor league Birmingham Barons, in 1964 -- 17 years after Robinson integrated the majors. And it has seen more than 50% of baseball Hall of Famers walk its grounds, from legendary Negro Leaguers like Mays, Josh Gibson and Satchel Paige to MLB greats Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Mickey Mantle.\n\n\"The majors? I didn't dream about the impossible,\" Mays recently told the San Francisco Chronicle. \"I was taught to see your goal in your mind and work toward it. I could work toward getting to Rickwood Field and the Birmingham Black Barons. I didn't need to dream for that. For that, I needed to work hard. So, I did. Rickwood became my training ground.\"\n\nMays became a star there at only 17 years old, helping the Black Barons reach the Negro League World Series in 1948. Major league scouts came to see him play, and the Black Barons were so popular locally that ministers sometimes preached early on Sundays to accommodate fans eager to attend games.\n\n\"Rickwood is special because it's where so many baseball careers began, and it's still standing,\" said Roy Wood Jr., a comedian and actor born in Birmingham. \"When you're there, you can still feel that history. I feel as strongly about Rickwood as someone would (feel) visiting their childhood home as an adult.\"\n\nWood played high school baseball at Rickwood Field in the 1990s. At the time, he said Rickwood was just another place for him to play the sport he loved. That changed when he learned the history.\n\n'A place where horror was allowed to take a pause'\n\nThe 10,800-seat stadium opened in 1910 during a time when baseball was the premier sport in Alabama. With few major league franchises in the South during those days, baseball fans in Alabama clung to minor league teams like the all-white Birmingham Barons, who played at Rickwood from 1910-1961, 1964-65 and 1981-87. Other white stars -- like Hall of Famers Ty Cobb and Honus Wagner -- came through Rickwood for spring exhibitions. Alabama and Auburn both used Rickwood as home fields for their college football teams.\n\nFor Black people, Rickwood and the Negro Leagues were an introduction to Black athletic talent.\n\n\"This league creates common heroes, common teams,\" said Rob Ruck, a historian focusing on Black and Latino roots in sport, \"a national institution that Black Americans rally around, and it gives them a collective self-esteem because of their abilities in sport.\"\n\nThe field was also a bright spot amid the fight for racial equality in the 1950s and 1960s. Alabama, one of the epicenters of the Civil Rights Movement, was the site of marches for voting rights and boycotts, as well as brutal beatings, civil unrest and deadly bombings.\n\n\"It was a place where horror was allowed to take a pause for nine innings,\" Wood said. \" ... Rickwood was never going to solve Black people's problems, but it represented a place where Black people didn't have to think about them for a few hours.\"\n\nMaintaining history\n\nThe ballpark is still standing against many odds. Built around the same time as Pittsburgh's Forbes Field, Philadelphia's Shibe Park, Chicago's Comiskey Park and Detroit's Tiger Stadium, Rickwood has outlasted them all, with high school and college games still being played there.\n\nWatkins and the Friends of Rickwood organization made up of about 30 volunteers have maintained it, along with others like Jabreil Weir, the head groundskeeper in charge of the field's day-to-day upkeep.\n\n\"Who would have thought MLB would come to Birmingham, Alabama?\" Weir said. \"Who ever thought that I would be in the position that I am to be a part of this event? These are moments that you dream of.\"\n\nWeir has worked with MLB in preparing the stadium to host a major league game. Renovations include a new field with lights, upgraded dugouts, a new drainage system and a new backstopping netting system to protect fans during the game, according to Murray Cook, MLB's field and stadium consultant.\n\nOther events have been held this week, including a Double-A game at the ballpark on Tuesday between the Birmingham Barons and Montgomery Biscuits of the Southern League. The game was paused while the PA announcer shared news of Mays' death, and fans reacted by standing, cheering and chanting \"Willie! Willie!\"\n\nThe game is part of an ongoing effort by MLB to highlight and celebrate achievements of Black players -- a push that comes amid criticism for a league where the percentage of Black major leaguers is historically low. MLB's endeavors have also included grassroots programs for underprivileged youth players and the recent integration of Negro Leagues statistics into its official records.\n\n\"This gives us an opportunity to talk about race in the context of sport,\" Ruck said, adding later, \"We've got to talk about race in serious ways, and I think this game, the stats, make that happen.\"\n\nSports Week {"uri": "8186117410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "00:37:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T00:37:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T00:35:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.wvua23.com/rickwood-field-prepares-for-mlb-showcase-with-minor-league-tune-up/", "title": "Rickwood Field prepares for MLB showcase with minor league tune-up - WVUA 23", "body": "The Birmingham Barons and Montgomery Biscuits faced off in the \"Rickwood Classic\" ahead of Thursday's MLB Field of Dreams matchup between the San Francisco Giants and St. Louis Cardinals.\n\nThe Biscuits came out on top in a 6-5 thriller in a game that served as a likely Southern League championship preview between the two teams at the top of their respective divisions.\n\nMore notably, it marked a homecoming for the Barons, who played at the stadium from its completion in 1910 through 1961. While Birmingham now plays at the newer Regions Field, it has played at least one game at the historic stadium nearly every year since 1981.\n\nBut yesterday's game held special significance as the entire baseball world will have its eyes on the venue and the entire city of Birmingham on Thursday. The two teams embodied the spirit of the week by playing under their respective cities' old Negro League names, the Birmingham Black Barons and Montgomery Grey Sox.\n\n\"When the guys showed up, they looked around they're like, 'This looks incredible,'\" Barons manager Sergio Santos said. \"It's amazing. It's a very unique game and something they're all grateful and appreciative to be a part of.\"\n\nIn addition to serving as the home for the Double-A Barons, Rickwood was notably the home of the Black Barons for over 20 years. Countless Negro League legends came through and played at the field, but one looms large over the upcoming game.\n\nThe entire baseball world came to a halt yesterday with the announcement that Willie Mays, possibly the greatest player to ever grace a baseball diamond, had passed away at the age of 93. Before becoming a 24-time all-star with the Giants and Mets, Mays made his professional debut with the Black Barons in 1948. Mays' passing was announced mid-game over the PA system, and the crowd honored the Hall of Famer with a standing ovation. Mays was expected to be honored at the game, but it was announced early this week that he would not be in attendance just two days before his passing.\n\nThursday's game will now serve as a commemoration of Mays' life and career, in addition to being a tribute to the Negro Leagues as a whole.\n\nThe game is only possible thanks to extensive renovations to the field. Over $5 million has been poured into repairing the venue over the past year to modernize the stadium and prepare it for an MLB-level audience.\n\n\"The upgrades they've done... over the last year -- replacing the entire field, extending the nets, redoing the dugouts -- all those are designed for player and fan safety,\" Barons General Manager Jonathan Nelson said. \"So not only does it enhance the overall experience, but it certainly extends the life of Rickwood Field.\"\n\nRickwood Field is possibly the most historically significant active ballpark in the sport. From Mays, Hank Aaron, Ernie Banks, Satchel Paige, Jackie Robinson, Josh Gibson, and Roy Campanella, who played there during their time in the Negro Leagues, to Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Ty Cobb, Mickey Mantle, Honus Wagner, Shoeless Joe Jackson, Joe DiMaggio, Yogi Berra, and Roberto Clemente, who played there in spring games, to Michael Jordan and Bo Jackson, who played there as members of the Barons, the story of Rickwood is the story of baseball and the story of American sports as a whole.", "source": {"uri": "wvua23.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WVUA23"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8187501935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:56:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_eaf111ce-dc72-5007-8ccc-792b87009595.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Iowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a homicide' Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Man dies in standoff with authorities in Sac County Former Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Boat speed rule imposed on Okoboji lakes in wake of heavy rains, storms that also led to wastewater discharges Sioux City man pleads not guilty of manslaughter Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Top area softball performers: RSM last unbeaten team; Mentzer, Moreau swinging hot bats Man pleads not guilty in Sioux City fatal hit and run\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad {"uri": "2024-06-395095041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:22:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:22:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:02:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://eu.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/sports/mlb/2024/06/19/greatest-baseball-players-to-play-at-rickwood-field/74150667007/", "title": "The greatest players to play at Rickwood Field included the Say Hey Kid, Hammer, Mr. Cub", "body": "Major League Baseball will host a special regular season game in Birmingham, Alabama between the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday. The game will be played at Rickwood Field, the oldest baseball park in the US.\n\nBuilt and opened in 1910, Rickwood Field was the first steel-and-concrete baseball stadium south of the Ohio River and the first built specifically for minor-league baseball. Rickwood hosted the Birmingham Barons and the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues for most of the 20th century. The MLB will use the game to pay tribute to the Negro Leagues and honor those who played in them.\n\nRickwood Field has been graced by many baseball legends in its storied history. Here are some of the most famous players to have played at Rickwood Field:\n\nWillie Mays\n\nOne of the greatest players of all time played his first professional games at Rickwood Field. Willie Mays, a native of Fairfield, Alabama, who passed away on Tuesday, attended high school just around the corner from Rickwood and signed his first contract with the Black Barons at the age of 17. He led the Black Barons to a Negro American League pennant and a Negro World Series appearance in 1948.\n\nMays signed with the New York Giants in 1950 and was playing in the majors by 1951. \"The Say Hey Kid\" was the NL Rookie of the Year and led the Giants to a National League pennant in 1951. In 1954, he was the NL MVP, and the Giants won the World Series. Mays was a 24-time All-Star and 12-time Golden Glove winner. He was a first-ballot Baseball Hall of Famer in 1979.\n\nSatchel Paige\n\nLeroy \"Satchel\" Paige joined the Black Barons in 1927 and played at Rickwood through 1929. In the 1929 season, Paige threw a Negro League record 176 strikeouts, though the actual number of strikeouts is disputed among various sources.\n\nPaige bounced around the Negro Leagues until 1948 when he signed his first major league contract with the Cleveland Indians. Paige became the oldest debutant in MLB history when he made his debut at 42 years and two days old. Still, he pitched in the major leagues until 1965, earning two All-Star nods and winning a World Series along the way. Paige played until he was 59, making him the oldest player in MLB history by nearly a decade.\n\nHank Aaron\n\nAnother all-time great, Hank Aaron got his start in the Negro American League with the Indianapolis Clowns. He likely only played a game or two at Rickwood with the Clowns, as his Negro League career only lasted 26 games before the Milwaukee Braves purchased his contract. However, the Braves played a spring exhibition series against the Brooklyn Dodgers at Rickwood during Aaron's first spring training in 1954, and he would often visit the field during spring training throughout his career.\n\nAaron's 755 career home runs stood as an MLB record for 33 years, and he still holds league records with 2,297 RBIs, 1,477 extra-base hits and 6,856 total bases.\n\nErnie Banks\n\n\"Mr. Cub\" played for the Kansas City Monarchs during his time in the Negro Leagues and played against the Black Barons at Rickwood. He was a 14-time All-Star and two-time NL MVP with the Chicago Cubs and was the first player in franchise history to have his number retired.\n\nJackie Robinson\n\nThe player who famously broke baseball's color barrier in 1948, Jackie Robinson played two games at Rickwood Field. Robinson and the Brooklyn Dodgers played a pair of exhibition games against Aaron and the Milwaukee Braves during the spring of 1954. The 2013 film \"42\" about Robinson's life features scenes shot on-location in Rickwood.\n\nReggie Jackson\n\nIn 1967, the Kansas City Athletics brought their Double-A farm team to Birmingham. Many of the players on that team became key parts of the A's 1972-74 World Series threepeat, including \"Mr. October,\" who was the AL MVP in 1973.\n\nBabe Ruth and Ty Cobb\n\nDespite never playing in the Negro Leagues, \"the Great Bambino\" and \"the Georgia Peach\" both played at Rickwood Field. The stadium's location near a railway hub made it convenient for traveling major leaguers to stop and see it on the way back from spring training to their home cities. Stopping to see the stadium often meant they would play an exhibition game there, and Ruth and Cobb were just two of the many legends who did so.\n\nLike Robinson's, Cobb's 1994 biopic, \"Cobb,\" was also shot on-location in Rickwood.", "source": {"uri": "eu.montgomeryadvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Montgomery Advertiser"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Amateur", "wgt": 26}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 31}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Board_Games/Sports", "label": "dmoz/Games/Board "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3568627450980393, "wgt": 178, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8186096022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "00:07:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T00:07:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T00:07:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/willie-mays-rickwood-field-negro-leagues-birmingham-black-barons-african-american-representation-mlb/", "title": "Following death of Willie Mays, Rickwood Field game takes on renewed significance", "body": "Birmingham, Alabama -- Before Willie Mays electrified fans with the New York Giants and made \"The Catch\" in the 1954 World Series, he patrolled centerfield at Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Alabama, as a teenager in 1948.\n\n\"Willie was something else,\" Rev. William Greason said of Mays, who died Tuesday at the age of 93. \"He had a gift that God gave him.\"\n\nGreason, now almost 100 years old, was Mays' teammate on the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues.\n\n\"The camaraderie that we had on that team, it was out of sight,\" said Greason, who added that, at the time, he had no idea he was playing alongside one of baseball's all-time greats.\n\n\"I just wanted to be a friend,\" Greason told CBS News.\n\nMays was too young to travel with the Black Barons, who barnstormed the Jim Crow South as a member of the Negro Southern League.\n\nAt Rickwood Field, which the Black Barons shared with the all-White Birmingham Barons, segregation was the enforced custom.\n\n\"When we played here, the Whites were in right field,\" Greason said. \"When they played, we were out there.\"\n\nSince 1910, 182 MLB Hall of Famers, both Black and White, have graced Rickwood's grounds. Legends like Reggie Jackson, Babe Ruth and \"Hammerin' Hank\" Aaron.\n\nWhen the St. Louis Cardinals play the San Francisco Giants at Rickwood Field Thursday in a game that will pay tribute to both Mays and the legacy of the Negro Leagues, Cardinals shortstop Masyn Winn will be a rarity -- an African American on a Major League roster.\n\n\"Being maybe the only Black person on the field is going to be pretty special for me to represent that out there,\" said Winn, acknowledging, though, that the situation speaks poorly of the state of African Americans in baseball right now.\n\n\"I think it just means we need more,\" Winn said.\n\nIn 1991, 18% of players on opening day rosters were African American, according to numbers from the Institute for Diversity and Ethics in Sport. This season, that is down to 6%.\n\nBut there are signs that could be changing. In 2022, four of the top five draft picks were African American. In 2021, MLB announced a $150 million investment aimed at increasing Black representation in baseball.\n\nAnd last month, statistics from the Negro Leagues were officially incorporated into MLB record books.\n\n\"I think it's cool to have that Black representation up there,\" Winn said of that move. \"I think it's good for the next generation.\"\n\nMLB had planned for Mays to attend the Rickwood game, a ballpark just six miles from Mays' boyhood home. Now, the field where Mays' baseball dreams began will poetically symbolize the end of that era and possibly the dawn of a new one.\n\n\"Many of those stats happened ... right here at Rickwood Field,\" Birmingham Mayor Randall Woodfin told CBS News. \"...What happened here is not just Black history, it's America's history. And the greats that came through this place, they literally went on to change what baseball meant.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8185913276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:26:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:26:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://thesource.com/2024/06/19/source-sports-exclusive-why-rickwood-field-will-be-the-epicenter-of-celebrating-the-life-of-willie-mays/", "title": "The Source |SOURCE SPORTS EXCLUSIVE: Why Rickwood Field Will Be The Epicenter Of Celebrating The Life Of Willie Mays", "body": "The best way non-baseball fans can understand is to describe him as the \"Michael Jordan of Baseball\" on the field, but off the diamond, his personality rivaled his performance. This is just a glimpse into why the commemoration of the Negro Leagues by Major League Baseball at the legendary Rickwood Field will be a three-day celebration of the life of baseball legend Willie Mays.\n\nVisit streaming.thesource.com for more information\n\nNot only is Rickwood Field one of the premiere stadiums of the Negro Leagues, where Mays began his professional baseball career as a member of the Birmingham Black Barons, but Birmingham, Alabama is also the birthplace of Mays, who's commonly known among baseball enthusiasts as the \"Say Hey Kid\". There will be an inaugural Juneteenth event that proceeds the big game between Mays' MLB alma mater San Francisco Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals. Wednesday's \"Birmingham Barnstorm\" Fam Jam Celebrity Softball Game is a face-off between Derek Jeter's \"Hammers\" honoring the late home run king Hank Aaron and Barry Bonds Jr.'s \"Sey Heys\", who are playing in the name of Bonds' godfather, who is none other than, you guessed it, Willie Mays. Bonds' who is currently Major League's asterisked all time home run leader, has always told intimate stores of his late godfather and because of their close relationship, this could be the reason that Bonds may not be able to serve as the Sey Heys' team captain today.\n\nThe main attraction will, of course, be tomorrow's game between the San Francisco Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals at the historic Birmingham field and to properly recognize the contributions of the Negro Leagues to what we know today as Major League Baseball, the two MLB teams will be wearing replicas of the Negro League uniforms. The Giants will be playing as the \"SeaLions\", which was a West Coast Negro League team based in San Francisco in 1946. West Virginia-born Marcenia Lyle Stone aka Toni Stone, began playing for the Sea Lions in 1949, becoming the first female to ever play in the Negro Leagues.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe St. Louis Cards will be donning \"St. Louis Stars\" uniforms, repping for the Negro National League's three-time champions, the St. Louis Stars. Playing from 1922-1931, the Stars' roster included several Negro League Hall Of Famers including Willie Wells, James Thomas Bell aka \"Cool Papa Bell\", Mule Nettles and others.\n\nAs described by MLB.com., \"fans will witness another kind of history as stars of entertainment, sports and baseball descend on Birmingham\" as the celebrity softball game, which will include notables such as Karen Civil, DC Young Fly, Terrell Owens, Omari Hardwick and a host of MLB legends including former Phillies star Jimmy Rollins, the Yankees' CC Sabathia and Alex Rodriguez, \"Big Papi\" David Ortiz, Adam Jones and countless others. The game will conclude with a feature performance by ATL super producer Metro Boomin, who will definitely bring out the crowds who aren't necessarily baseball fans.\n\nArguably the best all around player in baseball, the Birmingham-born \"King of the Diamond\" will definitely be honored in regal baseball fashion at Rickwood. The Negro League Baseball Museum will notably recognize Mr. Mays in all of the ceremonies, as the President of the NLBM Bob Kendrick gave this statement about the passing of Mays.\n\n\"All of us at the Negro League Baseball Museum are devastated by the news of the passing of the great Willie Mays. Willie so beautifully represented the heart and soul of everything that made the Negro Leagues special on the road to becoming a Hall of Famer and in the hearts and minds of many, the greatest Major Leaguer of all time. While our hearts are heavy, we'll remember and celebrate him for the unbridled joy he brought to the game! We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Mays family and his legion of fans worldwide.'\"\n\nThe Birmingham Barnstorm celebrity softball game wil begin tonight at 7PM EST while the Negro League Tribute will be held tomorrow(June 20) AT 6:15PM EST and can be seen on FOX Sports.\n\nMLB is extending the Rickwood Game \"Beyond the Ballpark\" to the Birmingham community at four local bars and restaurants on Thursday, June 20. {"uri": "2024-06-395550206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:41:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:41:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:26:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/rickwood-field-the-first-professional-ballpark-for-willie-mays-and-a-symbol-of-both-progress-and-challenges-is-ready-to-host-major-league-baseball/", "title": "Rickwood Field, the first professional ballpark for Willie Mays and a symbol of both progress and challenges, is ready to host Major League Baseball - Internewscast Journal", "body": "The game meant to honor Mays and many other Negro Leaguers will be both somber and reminiscent. Mays, the electrifying center fielder who left an enduring mark on baseball, died Tuesday, a day after announcing that he wouldn't attend the game in person.\n\n\"All of Major League Baseball is in mourning today as we are gathered at the very ballpark where a career and a legacy like no other began,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise. From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\n\"Rickwood is special because it's where so many baseball careers began, and it's still standing,\" said Roy Wood Jr., a comedian and actor born in Birmingham. \"When you're there, you can still feel that history. I feel as strongly about Rickwood as someone would (feel) visiting their childhood home as an adult.\"\n\n\"It was a place where horror was allowed to take a pause for nine innings,\" Wood said. \" ... Rickwood was never going to solve Black people's problems, but it represented a place where Black people didn't have to think about them for a few hours.\"\n\nThe game is part of an ongoing effort by MLB to highlight and celebrate achievements of Black players -- a push that comes amid criticism for a league where the percentage of Black major leaguers is historically low. MLB's endeavors have also included grassroots programs for underprivileged youth players and the recent integration of Negro Leagues statistics into its official records.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8186542424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:36:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:36:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:34:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/news/cardinals-giants-radio-station-channel-time-rickwood-field-game/ad30189d7e5e63ba95274284", "title": "Cardinals vs. Giants radio station: Channel, time for Rickwood Field MLB game and how to listen live for $1 on SiriusXM", "body": "Cardinals vs. Giants radio station: Channel, time for Rickwood Field MLB game and how to listen live for $1 on SiriusXM\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants, two of the perennial contenders in the NL, will face off in a historic game at Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Alabama on Thursday.\n\nThe event, officially dubbed \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A Tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" is the first of its kind and replaces MLB's recent \"Field of Dreams\" games in Iowa on the schedule.\n\nRickwood Field is the oldest professional baseball stadium in the country. It formerly served as the home field of the Birmingham Barons, the team Willie Mays played for in 1948.\n\nThe event, initially intended to honor the Negro Leagues, will now almost assuredly double as a tribute to the late great Mays, who Tuesday at age 93. Many baseball historians and MLB analysts consider Mays the greatest baseball player of all time.\n\nThe game itself should be competitive. The Cardinals and Giants, both of whom have begun heating up after poor starts to the season, are looking to stay on an upward trajectory.\n\nWant to listen to this historic NL clash?
