"eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-20", "textStart": 1718, "textEnd": 1725}], "sentiment": 0.2313725490196079, "wgt": 176, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187243667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:51:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:51:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:50:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.al.com/news/birmingham/2024/06/mlb-at-rickwood-a-way-of-reclaiming-birminghams-story.html", "title": "MLB at Rickwood: 'A way of reclaiming Birmingham's story'", "body": "On Thursday when the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants play at Rickwood Field, sounds of curve balls hitting bats and a roaring crowd may bring back fond memories to some Birmingham residents.\n\nFor decades, baseball was a neighborhood sport for children and adults, Black and white alike. And for decades, Rickwood hosted legendary Black and white baseball players - but Black players and fans were treated like second-class citizens.\n\nThose memories are bitter for some local civil rights activists and foot soldiers, who fought to tear down the segregation that crowded them into one corner of the park.\n\nJohn Alexander grew up on the west side of Birmingham, near Rickwood Field. He remembers setting up a folding chair in a friend's backyard so he could listen to broadcasts of the game.\n\n\"We couldn't go to Rickwood on the days when we wanted to go, but we did get a chance to experience it,\" he said.\n\nThe game at Rickwood, the oldest professional baseball stadium in the United States, will be the first in-season Major League Baseball game to be played in Alabama, although MLB recently integrated Negro League games into its history. It is billed as a tribute to the Negro Leagues. While the city's civil rights community continues seeking recognition in their fight for equality, other activists hope the Rickwood game will inspire a new legacy for the field.\n\n\"Of course there is room for improvement,\" Takia Hudson, a social justice activist, said. \"But I see unity in our communities because of sports. As they honor the Negro League, they honor humanity...The purpose of the game is to show the advancements that we as human beings have made. We also embrace the hardship that was required for this to be accomplished.\"\n\nThe city's response\n\n\"Since it was announced that the MLB would be coming to Birmingham, the Negro Southern League Museum has received an unprecedented amount of interest from national media, documentarians and visitors who all want to know more about these men and women and their contribution to baseball. This has regenerated newfound interest in the League and breathed new life into their stories,\" Marie Sutton, the City of Birmingham public information officer said.\n\n\"The City of Birmingham's celebration of these individuals is year-round. Each year, the Negro Southern League Museum hosts an annual luncheon in their honor, celebrates a community-wide Jackie Robinson Day and many other activities to highlight the contributions of these athletes who broke records in baseball and in the civil rights movement.\"\n\nThe Negro Southern League Museum partners with the city of Birmingham to bring the stories of the Negro League to Birmingham residents.\n\n\"I don't know that we've had much conversation with civil rights communities, I think in the future we'd like to include as much of the community in these conversations as possible,\" Anthony Williams, interim director of the Negro Southern League Museum, said.\n\nWilliams said that while the museum features a tribute to Rickwood Field, including a home base and uniform from the field's early days, he hopes to work with the civil rights community to include stories of activists and how baseball played a role in social justice movement.\n\n\"The museum's role is important as far as when all of this is over, people will still have a place to come and learn about all the things that have been the focus of national attention in these recent days,\" Williams said. \"From history we can carve out a new path that is unifying and that includes each citizen equally. I think the city's investment in this museum and in Rickwood is a way of reclaiming the story of Birmingham.\"\n\nMajor League Baseball representatives said the game is an investment in local community as A.G. Gaston Construction, a local Black owned company, is the primary contractor for the field's $5 million refurbishment; more than 200 part-time employment opportunities for all Rickwood events were given to local residents; and a financial program to support Negro Leagues players was expanded.\n\nCommunity members are highlighting the efforts of civil rights activists in the lead-up to the game. Efforts include a podcast hosted by Roy Wood Jr. featuring Negro League veterans and the legacy of Black baseball on the city's social justice movement; the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute displaying a 24-foot Willie Mays baseball card outside the museum; and a Negro Leagues Family Alliance Bruncheon and Reception hosted at the Negro Southern League Museum.\n\nActivists say it's important for Major League Baseball, and fans watching the June 20 game, to recognize the work it took to get to this moment.\n\nMemories of Rickwood Field: 'The good, the bad and the ugly'\n\nFor decades, baseball weaved its way into every aspect of Birmingham city life. It was a part of children's dreams, Birmingham's path to industrialization and even local civil rights history.\n\nAnd Rickwood was the center of that history.\n\nWilliam Merriweather III, a 72-year-old foot soldier in the civil rights movement, said his first experience at a game at Rickwood, 60 years ago, kept him from ever wanting to return.\n\n\"We had a hard time trying to go to the baseball game because it was really for whites. Being a child, you asked your daddy, 'Can we go to a baseball game,' and daddy would say, 'There might be repercussions because of the color of your skin,'\" Merriweather said.\n\nWhen his father finally gave in and took his family out to a Rickwood game, Merriweather said he remembers being questioned by white patrons and having to sit in the Blacks-only section of the stadium. Rickwood desegregated in 1964.\n\n\"I always wanted to go see Willie Mays and the Black Barons but couldn't because of the color of my skin,\" Merriweather said. \"It didn't sit right with me as a child.\"\n\nMerriweather said he hopes the city can right these wrongs by giving free Rickwood tickets to local community members and foot soldiers.\n\nTerry Collins, another foot soldier, said baseball was all around him when he was growing up.\n\nAt the time, the Birmingham Housing Authority created baseball teams for every neighborhood, for all ages.\n\nAs a child, Collins looked up to Willie Young, a one-handed American Negro League pitcher for the Birmingham Black Barons. Collins also remembers his father selling bags of peanuts to raise money for a youth baseball team.\n\n\"Rickwood Field played a major role in African American baseball,\" Collins said. \"Baseball was a major component in the Black community.\"\n\nCollins said he wished the city had done more to include the civil rights community, foot soldiers and activists, to highlight the efforts to bring the historic game to a place so tied to the human rights movement.\n\n\"The importance of baseball, the significance of it, is changed because of integration,\" Collins said.\n\nFor John Alexander and his friends, learning about the success of the Black Barons inspired them despite the discrimination they knew the players faced.\n\n\"Baseball was a way out for our Black youth,\" Alexander said.\n\nAt 18, Alexander began coaching youth baseball teams with the Birmingham Housing Authority, which he did for more than 20 years. Alexander said some of his teachers even played for the Black Barons, including Freddy Shepard and Wiley Griggs.\n\nBirmingham has had ample opportunities to invest in youth sports, such as the plan for Major League Baseball to build a $10 million baseball facility that was abandoned because of \"Birmingham politics,\" various foot soldiers said.\n\nAlexander said he wishes the city would invest more money and effort into youth sports like it once had.\n\n\"They always said baseball was a white man's game, but that just wasn't so because we had baseball when we didn't have anything else,\" Alexander said.\n\nThe activist Takia Hudson grew up two blocks away from Rickwood Field. The last baseball game Hudson ever played was at Rickwood, as a pitcher for Jackson-Olin High School.\n\nHis aunt worked at Rickwood and caught the foul balls to give to her nephew. He remembers how his mother used to sneak the neighborhood kids in through the back gate at Rickwood.\n\n\"Those are the sorts of things that made Rickwood what it was, the good, the bad and the ugly,\" Hudson said.\n\n\"It takes us back down memory lane for the community that embraced baseball,\" Hudson said. \"For MLB to come, it's just another level of excitement because that's the best of the best of baseball around the world in our neighborhood. It lets us know that the efforts of the foot soldiers and the efforts of civil rights leaders have not been totally in vain.\"", "source": {"uri": "al.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "al"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negro_Southern_League_(1920\u20131936)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Negro Southern League (1920\u20131936)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickwood_Field", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rickwood Field"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Baseball"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Major League Baseball"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_and_political_rights", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Civil and political rights"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Birmingham"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Birmingham"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_A._Williams", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Anthony A. {"uri": "2024-06-396261333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:02:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:02:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_7438e799-86c7-569a-8181-975c294366aa.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb\n\nCardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field\n\nDerrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nPizza Hut restaurants abruptly close across Northwest Indiana after franchisee is accused of defaulting on payments Davich: Pizza Hut manager's first clue of abrupt closing: 'Fatal error' NWI Business Ins and Outs: True BBQ closed; Birdie's Diner, Next Door at Birdie's, Broad Street Tavern, Whihala Ice Cream, Lenny's Coal-Fired Pizza and Beauty and the Bronze opening Overnight closures of Northwest Indiana's Pizza Huts were years in the making, court records show Family of Crown Point ironworker sues after 100-floot plunge at University of Chicago Hospital, faced with 'life-altering, catastrophic injuries' Downtown Valparaiso has been named a quiet zone Lake Central outlasts Mooresville to win second state title Downtown, racetrack, Kennedy Avenue projects moving ahead in Schererville Crown Point man, 73, sent to prison over his role in Jan. 6 Capitol breach, feds say Franciscan Health building a $185.5 million, five-story hospital addition in Munster Portage police shoot man with gun; investigation underway, county says Second person dies in wake of alleged OWI crash; charge enhanced, records show Man dead after being burned Monday in garage fire, officials say Pedestrian struck in fatal crash identified by coroner New stores open at Lighthouse Place Premium Outlets\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly {"uri": "8186171807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:51:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:51:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:49:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.wbrc.com/2024/06/20/city-birmingham-mlb-pay-tribute-willie-mays-negro-leagues/", "title": "City of Birmingham, MLB pay tribute to Willie Mays and the Negro Leagues", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (WBRC) - A week of celebration turning somber, as one of Alabama's greatest athletes has passed away.\n\nReaction has poured in from across the country after Willie Mays, \"The Say Hey Kid,\" died Tuesday at the age of 93.\n\nThe San Francisco Giants announced the passing of Mays Tuesday night, just two days before they're set to play in Birmingham at Rickwood Field.\n\nMays, a Westfield native, started his illustrious career with the Birmingham Black Barons before becoming a 24-time MLB All-Star and one of only nine people to hit 600 home runs in his career.\n\nThere has been an outpouring of condolences and tributes to Mays as the eyes of the baseball world are on Birmingham.\n\nOn Wednesday, a brunch was held at the Negro Southern League Museum, a facility set aside to preserve and tell the history of the Negro Leagues.\n\nDuring the brunch, folks celebrated and honored the Negro Leagues and their records finally being included among MLB records.\n\nDoug Foster, who is related to Andrew Foster, the founder of the Negro Leagues, and Bill Foster, a Hall of Fame pitcher, said he was saddened by the news of Willie Mays' passing because he was such an inspiration.\n\nBut Foster says events like these give us the opportunity to remember their legacy.\n\n\"He played the sport of baseball, and he was successful unlike any other. So obviously, very disappointed but again this is an opportunity to highlight his contributions along with other Negro League players, so we're going to take advantage of the moment, and really use his passing as a way to honor him and other Negro League players,\" Foster said.\n\nIn addition to the brunch, a mural honoring Hays was unveiled Wednesday, June 19.\n\nThe mural was designed by artist Chuck Styles and focuses on Mays' Hall of Fame career, including his time playing for the Birmingham Black Barons.\n\n\"He really brought a certain pizzazz to baseball that wasn't there before and he kind of pioneered the era of the replay. We need to see that play again because it was so special andI think that speaks to the type of athlete that we have in this area and just how special sports means to people in this region,\" said Anthony Williams, director of the Negro Southern League Museum.\n\nLots of folks came out to see the mural, including Birmingham Mayor Randall Woodfin, who was also saddened when he heard the news of Mays' passing.\n\nWoodfin says with it being Juneteenth, there is no better day to celebrate him than on a day that celebrates Black excellence.\n\nThe mural means so much more now that Mays has passed on. His legacy and impact will be remembered for years to come.\n\nThese events are all leading up to the MLB at Rickwood Field game on Thursday, June 20.", "source": {"uri": "wbrc.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-394979190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:56:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:56:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:35:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.aol.com/legacies-josh-gibson-negro-leagues-163535034.html", "title": "Legacies of Josh Gibson, Negro Leagues players go beyond statistical recognition", "body": "Although the Negro Leagues star and his family received a ton of attention following Major League Baseball's decision to enter Negro Leagues stats into the major-league record books, the entries brought a newfound recognition for the legacies of many players of that era and their families.\n\n\"This is a long time coming,\" Sean Gibson, the great-grandson of Josh Gibson, told Yahoo Sports. \"This announcement was made back in December of 2020, and here we are three-and-a-half years later, and it's finally come together, and we're very excited.\n\n\"It's better late than never. All these great players that they're talking about are no longer with us. But as far as the family members, it's exciting for us to carry on that legacy through our family members who played in the Negro Leagues.\"\n\nGibson's name is brought up for obvious reasons. With the addition of the Negro Leagues stats, the Pittsburgh Crawfords and Homestead Grays star became MLB's career leader in batting average, slugging percentage and OPS, as well as the holder of the single-season records in each of those categories. Passing legends such as Ty Cobb and Babe Ruth etched Gibson's name firmly in baseball history.\n\nFor that reason, Topps and Fanatics Collectibles have signed a multi-year contract extension with Gibson's estate and will include Gibson in the Topps MLB at Rickwood Field series this month, ensuring that the legacy of Josh Gibson will continue to be told in the form of collectible trading cards.\n\nTopps has been making cards with Gibson since 2001. Since 2015, the company has made 31 cards, including this year's releases in the 2024 Allen and Ginter set and the 2024 Tribute Base Cards, among others.\n\n\"I think given the momentum of the Rickwood game, as well as the Negro Leagues properly and finally being included in MLB record books, it only made sense to extend our relationship with Josh Gibson and the family,\" Omar Wilkes, head of athlete partnerships at Fanatics Collectibles, told Yahoo Sports.\n\n\"I think it's our duty to use our platform and our history of having a world-class trading card product connected with baseball to amplify and kind of keep his legacy going on forever.\"\n\nYet even with the new contract and the newfound attention and praise, the Gibson family never needed MLB's sign of approval or validation that Gibson's accolades mattered.\n\n\"We always considered our Negro League family members major leaguers anyways,\" Sean Gibson said. \"It's just that Major League Baseball didn't recognize them as major leaguers.\"\n\nThe words \"Negro League family members\" isn't just a term of endearment. Gibson, along with other descendants of Negro Leagues players, created the Negro League Family Alliance. The group's mission is \"to collectively preserve the legacies, history and intellectual properties of the Negro Leagues,\" according to their website.\n\nOne member of that group is former Negro Leagues player Ron \"Schoolboy\" Teasley. Following the death of Willie Mays on Tuesday, the 97-year-old Teasley and 99-year-old Bill Greason are the only two living players from the Negro Leagues era.\n\nTeasley is one of the few players from that time who got to see the Negro Leagues statistics added to the major league records during his lifetime. Willie Mays, who played for the Birmingham Black Barons, was another, seeing his hit total rise by 10.\n\nThat's arguably the thing that means the most for Gibson after years of fighting for the stats incorporation.\n\n\"This was something I really wanted to do before he passed away. He played with the New York Cubans in 1948,\" he said. \"I'm excited to see Mr. Teasley get a chance to see his name and officially [be in the] MLB record book. I'm really excited about that.\"\n\nGibson will be representing his family's estate during MLB's Rickwood Field game between the San Francisco Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals on Thursday. As part of the deal with Topps, an 18 x 24, 8,000-pound card of Gibson from the pre-Rickwood game tour will be given to the Josh Gibson Foundation.\n\nWhile it's certainly too large to fit into a pocket or collectible trading card sleeve, Gibson already has an idea of where the foundation will put the massive piece of memorabilia.\n\n\"We definitely wanna have that card in Pittsburgh,\" he said. \"But I feel like right now, with the way Josh is being talked about through the MLB record books, that card has to be in Pittsburgh for some point, for some period of time.\"", "source": {"uri": "8187377527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:22:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:22:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:21:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://fox2now.com/sports/st-louis-cardinals/watch-the-cardinals-giants-rickwood-field-game-thursday-on-fox-2/", "title": "Watch the Cardinals-Giants Rickwood Field game Thursday on FOX 2", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - The St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants are set for a unique matchup Thursday at Rickwood Field.\n\nThe game will serve as a tribute to the Negro Leagues. And FOX 2 will carry the game broadcast.\n\nFirst pitch is scheduled for 6:15 p.m. CT on Thursday. Before then, the MLB on FOX Pregame show will air from 4:30-6 p.m. CT on FOX 2.\n\nRickwood Field was the former home of the Negro Leagues' Birmingham Black Barons and America's oldest-standing professional ballpark this season. The Cardinals and Giants plans to wear uniforms that commemorate two former Negro League baseball teams in the St. Louis Browns and San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nThe game will also consist of several tributes to the Negro Leagues, commemorate the Juneteenth holiday and pay respects to fallen MLB Hall-Of-Famer Willie Mays.", "source": {"uri": "fox2now.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fox2Now"}, {"uri": "8187136282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:42:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:42:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:41:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "http://theatlantavoice.com/from-rickwood-to-the-major-leagues/", "title": "From Rickwood to the Major Leagues", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, AL. - Rickwood Field, the oldest ballpark in the state of Alabama, is where legends were born. It has been a sanctuary for many of baseball's greatest players, including iconic figures from the Negro Leagues. Satchel Paige, known for his incredible pitching ability and showmanship, amazed crowds with his fastball and charisma. The late Willie Mays, who started his career with the Birmingham Black Barons, showcased his five-tool talent that would later make him a Major League Baseball star and Hall of Fame inductee. The legendary Josh Gibson, often referred to as the \"Black Babe Ruth,\" captivated fans with his extraordinary hitting power, leaving an indescribable mark on the sport.\n\nFans inside Rickwood Field witnessed countless memorable moments, serving as a cultural and historical cornerstone for over a century. From its charming wooden grandstands to the timeless feel of its diamond, Rickwood Field continues to evoke nostalgia and reverence among baseball enthusiasts.\n\nThis hallowed ground, where dreams have been realized and history made, truly embodies \"the field of dreams.\"\n\nWhat Was\n\nRickwood Field, established in 1910, stands as a monument to baseball's rich history and enduring legacy. Built by industrialist Rick Woodward, it quickly became a central hub for America's pastime. The field's opening game on August 18, 1910, saw the Birmingham Barons face off against the Montgomery Climbers, setting the stage for over a century of baseball excellence.\n\nThe importance of Rickwood Field extends beyond its status as the oldest surviving professional baseball park. It played a crucial role in the development and integration of baseball. During the segregation era, Rickwood was a primary venue for Negro League games, hosting teams like the hometown Birmingham Black Barons. The field became a stage where Black players could showcase their talents, breaking down racial barriers and paving the way for the integration of Major League Baseball.\n\nRickwood Field's historical significance is further highlighted by its continuous use for baseball and its preservation as a living museum. It has seen countless future Hall of Famers grace its diamond, including legends from both the Major Leagues and Negro Leagues. The field has also served as a cultural gathering place for the Birmingham community, hosting everything from minor league games to vintage baseball events.\n\nRickwood Field is not just a ballpark; it's a testament to the enduring spirit of baseball. As \"the field of dreams,\" it continues to inspire new generations of players and fans, celebrating the sport's storied past while looking forward to its future.\n\nA Groundbreaking Shift\n\nFrom the sweet home of Rickwood Field to the major leagues, the Negro Leagues are finally getting the recognition they deserve. In May of 2024, Major League Baseball (MLB) officially integrated the statistics of the Negro Leagues, and these stats have made significant changes to what we thought we knew about baseball history.\n\nThe recent integration of Negro League statistics into the MLB records marks a groundbreaking shift in the landscape of baseball history. This significant move has led to substantial revisions in historical records, placing Negro League legends in their deserved places among baseball's all-time greats. One of the most remarkable outcomes of this integration is that Josh Gibson, often celebrated as the \"Black Babe Ruth,\" now stands atop several key statistical categories, highlighting his extraordinary talent and contributions to the sport.\n\nJosh Gibson: The New Number One\n\nWith the inclusion of Negro League stats, Josh Gibson's incredible achievements are now officially recognized by MLB. Gibson's career statistics are nothing short of phenomenal, and their inclusion has catapulted him to the top of several of the games beloved categories.\n\nGibson's career batting average, now recognized as .365, is among the highest in baseball history, surpassing the averages of many MLB legends. While the exact numbers are debated, Gibson is credited with hitting between 800 and 1,000 home runs over his career, which places him ahead of Barry Bonds' MLB record of 762 home runs. Gibson's career slugging percentage is estimated to be around .690, which would place him at the top of this category, surpassing even Babe Ruth's .690. These statistics not only highlight Gibson's dominance but also emphasize the exceptional level of talent that existed within the Negro Leagues.\n\nWhat does this mean for the MLB\n\nThe inclusion of Negro League statistics serves as a vital correction of the historical record, acknowledging the immense contributions of Black players who were prohibited from MLB due to racial segregation. This move ensures that their legacies are preserved and celebrated within the broader context of baseball history.\n\nThis change also holds profound cultural and social significance. By formally acknowledging the achievements of Negro League players, MLB is making a powerful statement about the importance of diversity and inclusion in sports and society. It highlights the need to rectify historical injustices and honor the talent that was overlooked for decades.\n\nThe Impact\n\nThe integration of Negro League statistics into MLB records is a pivotal moment in baseball history. Josh Gibson's rise to the top bit only symbolizes a correction of historical records, but a celebration of the extraordinary talent that was unjustly excluded from the MLB for decades. This integration changes it the narrative of baseball, making it more inclusive and representative of all the great athletes who have played the game. Through this recognition, MLB honors the legacy of the Negro Leagues and ensures that their contributions are forever remembered and celebrated.", "source": {"uri": "theatlantavoice.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8187477028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:38:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:38:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:37:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_542d2706-c1a9-54f5-9669-39a66769376f.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Comedian Pete Davidson shops local ahead of Bloomington shows Rivian announces next set of company-wide layoffs Juror dismissed in McLean County murder trial for suspected 'bias' towards defendant Jaylin Bones found guilty in 2022 Bloomington murder Bloomington rapper bringing it home with album release party at Normal West Downed power lines and poles cause road closures in McLean County Over 55,000 expected for Tailgate N' Tallboys music fest in Bloomington First night of Tailgate N' Tallboys canceled due to severe weather Videos, phone data show murder defendant's path to Chicago after fatal Bloomington shooting Bloomington woman in custody on murder charges in rural McLean County shooting Michael Mounce survives late push to capture Bloomington-Normal Match Play championship Flick Fact: Today's biggest rip-offs that we all pay? At Bloomington's Mobile Pride Parade, a celebration of joy and acceptance State: Murder defendant fought Bloomington man over a gun before fatal shooting Aaron Rossi accused of defrauding state of Illinois during COVID-19 pandemic\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry {"uri": "8187677360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:36:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:36:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:34:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.wvua23.com/giants-vs-cardinals-at-rickwood-field-to-commemorate-the-life-of-willie-mays/", "title": "Giants vs. Cardinals at Rickwood Field to commemorate the life of Willie Mays - WVUA 23", "body": "Thursday's game is first time an MLB game will be played in Alabama\n\nThe baseball world has a heavy heart right after Willie Mays passed away at the age of 93 on Tuesday, June 18.\n\nJust two days after the tragic news, the St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants are set to face off in the place Mays called home: Rickwood Field in Birmingham. The week surrounding the game itself and Juneteenth has been spent honoring icons such as Mays that paved the way for progress to be made in society and on the baseball diamond.\n\nMays grew up in Westfield, Alabama, where he dreamed of playing at Rickwood Field for the Birmingham Black Barons. He debuted for his hometown club as a 17-year-old in 1947, the same year Jackie Robinson integrated professional baseball in the United States. He made his major league debut in 1951 and won two MVPs and the 1954 World Series. He was selected to 24 all-star teams and elected to the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York.\n\nHe is widely considered one of if not the greatest players to ever play baseball, nonetheless the Giants. While he was not expected to attend Thursday's game due to his health, the baseball world hoped Mays would see the appreciation baseball fans had for him.\n\nThe San Francisco Giants (36-39) will hope to honor Mays, a team legend, with a victory Thursday night against the St. Louis Cardinals (36-37). Both teams are below .500 and on two-game losing streaks. Just one game will be played at Rickwood, before the two travel to St. Louis to wrap up the three-game series on Saturday and Sunday.\n\nKeaton Winn (3-7) will take the mound for the Giants and square off against the Cardinals' Andre Pallante (2-3). The Cardinals had the best record in the National League over its past 27 games, before losing two of three games in Miami.\n\nBoth teams are wearing commemorative jerseys honoring the Negro League teams of each city: the San Francisco Sea Lions and the St. Louis Stars. The Giants and the Cardinals have both stitched patches with the No. 24 in black and orange to honor Mays tonight.\n\nThe Cardinals filmed a video in the pre-season in which players described what Mays meant to baseball and their anticipation to play at Rickwood Field.\n\n\"The ability [of Mays] to break those barriers is amazing,\" Cardinals utility player Brendan Donovan said. \"I'm actually from Alabama so I know all about Rickwood Field. It's truly special to get to play here.\"\n\n\"Obviously one of the biggest names in baseball history,\" Cardinals shortstop Masyn Winn said. \"You hear a name like that you think Hank Aaron, Ozzie Smith, Jackie Robinson and all those Black legends. Super excited to be a part of that history.\"\n\nRickwood Field is the oldest professional baseball field that is still operative in the United States. Once a playing fortress for 30% of MLB Hall of Famers, the field has been used for special occasions such as Thursday night's game but also as a filming site for 42, which displays the career of Jackie Robinson.\n\nFirst pitch is set for 6:15 p.m. and will be broadcast nationally on Fox. {"uri": "8187485573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:44:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:44:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:43:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/newsletter/fos-pm-mlb-changes-rickwood-plans/", "title": "FOS PM: MLB Changes Rickwood Plans - Front Office Sports", "body": "MLB's Rickwood Game Plans Change Significantly After Passing of Mays\n\nMajor League Baseball's strategy for staging special-event games is taking a new and dramatic turn with Thursday's game at Rickwood Field in Alabama, but the league's leaders are doing so with heavy hearts after the death this week of one of the game's all-time greats.\n\nThe league will stage a game between the Giants and Cardinals tonight at the historic Birmingham park that opened in 1910 and hosted Negro Leagues games for decades. The event, announced last year, marks MLB's first competition at a historic Negro Leagues field and extends a recent run of U.S.-based games held at nontraditional locations, including the Field of Dreams movie site in Iowa, the Little League complex in Pennsylvania, Fort Liberty in North Carolina, and the College World Series site in Nebraska.\n\nWillie Mays (above), one of the foremost icons of baseball, played as a teenager at Rickwood, the oldest professional ballpark in the U.S. When the game was first scheduled, part of the idea was to celebrate the Hall of Famer. But he issued a statement Monday saying he would not be able to travel from California to Alabama. The following day, he died at the age of 93 of heart failure. Mays's Baseball Hall of Fame plaque is on display at Rickwood, a move planned before his death, and memorializing his legacy will be a central part of both the in-venue game operations and the national broadcast coverage on Fox.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nThe Rickwood game required an extensive overhaul by MLB and field consultant BrightView, stretching more than a year, to bring the aging facility up to league code for a regular-season game. The event is also the centerpiece of a much larger recognition by MLB of the often-overlooked contribution of the Negro Leagues to baseball. Last month, the league formally incorporated former Negro Leagues players into its official statistics, allowing players who were banned from MLB due to segregation to be considered in the same way as white players.\n\nSince the history and statistics of baseball are integral to the overall fandom and culture of the sport, a move such as this arguably resonates much more than if it happened elsewhere. This also likely will have significant impacts on future inductions to the Hall of Fame, which also can produce a sizable influx of income for those players and the Cooperstown, N.Y., shrine itself.\n\nThe Hall of Fame has also been an active participant in the broader commemoration, recently holding its Hall of Fame East-West Classic, a tribute to the Negro Leagues East-West All-Star Game that ran annually from 1933 to '62.\n\nMLB, meanwhile, continues to push for greater diversity, both on the field and off. Black people comprise 6% of major league rosters, down from 18% 30 years ago, and standing at the lowest level since the Institute for Diversity and Ethics in Sport began tracking this data in the early 1990s.\n\nBut people of color such as the Yankees' Aaron Judge and Dodgers' Mookie Betts represent some of the sport's biggest stars. Recent draft classes have also shown greater percentages of Black people, suggesting improvement to come at the major league level in future years.", "source": {"uri": "frontofficesports.com", {"uri": "8186155883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:29:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:29:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:28:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/sanfrancisco/news/mlb-to-officially-recognize-negro-league-players-rightful-place-in-baseball-history/", "title": "MLB's addition of Negro League players' stats helps rectify baseball history", "body": "The MLB officially recognized the contributions the Negro League made to baseball, and it's something that has been years in the making through the effort of various people.\n\nLegendary play-by-play announcer Jon Miller still dreams of baseball, and sometimes, of when the mic gets taken away.\n\n\"I have stress dreams sometimes when they said that I couldn't do this anymore,\" said Miller.\n\nThe 72-year-old has been studying baseball his entire life, including players from the Negro Leagues, now being recognized in Major League Baseball's record books.\n\n\"These were big leaguers who were excluded. It wasn't because they never made it to the big league. They weren't allowed to play in the big leagues,\" said Miller.\n\nAs the country celebrates Juneteenth this week, the San Francisco Giants are honoring Negro League players who are being recognized in a new way.\n\nThe Giants are playing Thursday on the field where Willie Mays first played in the Negro Leagues. Giants all-time great Willie Mays, who died on Tuesday, started his professional career as a Birmingham Black Baron.\n\nBaseball now has a generation of stars from the past, being seen in a whole different light. MLB's inclusion of Negro League stats is an inflection point, as stars like Josh Gibson have catapulted to the top of some of baseball's most heralded records.\n\n\"Very little is known, I think of Oscar Charleston. Turkey Stearns is another guy. There are so many names like that,\" said Miller.\n\nThursday's Juneteenth game at Rickwood Field, is a tribute to baseball's trailblazers, who were equally if not more talented, but denied equality, because of the color of their skin.\n\n\"There are some great players that played in the Negro Leagues during those times, no more than when you talk about a guy like Willie Mays, you understand that,\" said Giants Manager Bob Melvin.\n\n\"The big league story, the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown which is the story of baseball, it's not ever been complete because all those names have been missing,\" said Miller.\n\nIt is a journey decades in the making, to retrieve and vet statistics from the seven Negro Leagues by fans, journalists, historians, and families of players who have passed, but are not forgotten.\n\n\"A lot of people put in a lot of time like detective work to find out who these players were,\" said Miller. \"I think that's a boon to baseball fans.\"\n\nThe Hall of Fame broadcaster has a prime seat to weave a new history of the game, into a more fully encompassing story.\n\n\"The stats will tell you a certain part of that story about how great they were in their careers, but the rest of it still has to be an oral history,\" said Miller.\n\nAnd there was no one better to do that than the voice of the San Francisco Giants. Willie Mays, who was 93 years old, was asked to do it, but had said he was unable to join the festivities of the Juneteenth game in Birmingham, Alabama, on Thursday.\n\nThe Giants organization on Tuesday announced Mays had died.\n\nThis will be Major League Baseball's first regular-season game at Rickwood Field.\n\nIt's the oldest still-existing professional ballpark in the country.", "https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/06/20/c169e1e5-cfc7-48c8-9b93-3f4102daff0f/thumbnail/1200x630/598048ea24a34df3bd069c8e4320edd9/negroleagueplayrs.jpg?v=5842509bb796a146f9b20d3e8b03dac6", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1215686274509804, "wgt": 168, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187478497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:41:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:41:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:38:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_b81c4372-148b-53c3-be12-ec1146c4c619.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... CHP: Angwin woman dies after car strikes her on driveway Suspect named in fatal Napa County hit-and-run crash Napa Valley College's new student housing: How much will it cost? The Bird joins Super Duper Burgers in Napa Man charged in Lake Berryessa murder pleads not guilty Costco asks for more parking at Napa store as construction progresses Napa Town & Country Fair announces musicians, opens ticket sales Man injured in tubing accident in Lake Berryessa Wind machine displayed in downtown St. Helena draws $500 fine Barbie comes to wine country: Napa Toy Museum hosts vintage Barbie exhibit Regional Italian pizzas coming to Napa Valley Wildfire smoke prompts Napa County air advisory Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Update: Sonoma wineries follow Point Fire's progress; air quality alerts to end Tuesday Red-flag fire risk warning called for Northern California, but not Napa County\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\nLocations Stlouis Be the first to {"uri": "8187037977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:41:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:41:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:40:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/professional/mlb/cardinals/mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama-media/collection_e31a626a-2a8d-11ef-92ac-97489802599f.html", "title": "Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama: Media Views", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the Cardinals facing the Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox (KTVI, Channel 2 locally) begins at 4:30 p.m. with the first pitch scheduled for 6:15 p.m. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nMLB Network will be carrying shows from Rickwood throughout the day. At noon, \"MLB Central\" airs, followed at 1:30 by a celebrity softball game. At 3 o'clock is \"MLB Tonight,\" which is hosted by St. Charles native Greg Amsinger and has former Cardinals pitcher Adam Wainwright among the analysts. \"MLB Tonight\" then returns after the game.\n\nOn radio, Cardinals broadcasters John Rooney, Ricky Horton and Mike Claiborne are to be on hand and pregame programming begins at 5:20 p.m. In addition to KMOX (1120 AM) and the team's regular radio network, the contest will air locally on WFUN (96.3 FM), a rhythm and blues station owned by KMOX parent company Audacy.\n\nCardinals Spanish-language broadcasters Polo Ascencio and Bengie Molina also will call the game, albeit via monitors in Busch Stadium. That airs locally on WIJR (880 AM), the rest of the team's Spanish network plus on Sirius XM Radio.", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 166, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187476025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:38:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:38:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/mlb/willie-mays-death-shifts-focus-for-mlb-fox-with-historic-cardinals-giants-game-in-alabama/article_597009bf-1ed1-5694-b588-aa7bc95c23b7.html", "title": "Willie Mays' death shifts focus for MLB, Fox with historic Cardinals-Giants game in Alabama", "body": "It was supposed to be a night spent honoring the legacy of baseball's Negro Leagues, in a festive atmosphere in the Deep South while also celebrating the career of exquisite alum Willie Mays -- all on the field in Birmingham, Alabama, where his pro career began in 1948 with his hometown Black Barons.\n\nThose activities were intended to punctuate the first big league regular-season game to be played in the state with the St. Louis Cardinals facing the San Francisco Giants, the team Mays represented on the field for 21 seasons in his Hall of Fame career, with the entire proceedings being showcased in a national telecast by Fox.\n\nMlb Cardinals, Giants to run basepaths blazed by Negro League pioneers at Rickwood Field Derrick Goold St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMays, at 93 the oldest living MLB player, planned to attend but pulled out on Monday, saying he'd follow the game from his San Francisco-area home. But he died Tuesday, thus shifting the focus of the events.\n\nPeople are also reading... Marion woman charged with sexual exploitation of a child McDowell schools recognizes student for science competition success; staff for dedication McDowell deputies stop car for traffic violation, find meth in search Don't throw out that mail: many NC families set to receive 'SUN Bucks' to help feed children this summer Update: Runaway teen located Man arrested for stealing vehicle, wallet of man who died in Old Fort McDowell alum Zach Franklin having a solid first half for Winston-Salem Dash Developer seeking federal money for $50 million Clinchfield mill housing project Olive Garden planned for former Fatz Cafe building in Morganton McDowell sheriff's office looking for suspect, car in armed robbery case 2 McDowell County residents earn university honors for spring 2024 Old Fort leaders approve 5-cent property tax increase McDowell leaders look at finding coordinator for trails Mission Health Center McDowell welcomes new pediatric surgeon Marion property tax may rise if budget is approved; public hearing Tuesday\n\n\"Thursday's game at historic Rickwood Field was designed to be a celebration of Willie Mays and his peers,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"With sadness in our hearts, it will now also serve as a national remembrance of an American who will forever remain on the short list of the most impactful individuals our great game has ever known.\"\n\nThe setting will be Rickwood, which opened in 1910 and not only is the oldest facility still operating in baseball but has rich ties to the Negro Leagues as it was the home of the Black Barons.\n\n\"Willie Mays took his all-around brilliance from the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro American League to the historic Giants franchise,\" Manfred added. \"From coast to coast in New York and San Francisco, Willie inspired generations of players and fans as the game grew and truly earned its place as our National Pastime.\"\n\nThe evening is being called \"MLB at Rickwood Field: A tribute to the Negro Leagues,\" and the coverage on Fox begins at 5:30 p.m. ET with the first pitch scheduled for 7:15 p.m. ET. The network plans to go all out with its telecast in focusing on the historical aspect of the event as well as the game itself. While Mays tributes being shown are a given, exact plans for some coverage was in flux late Wednesday because of his death.\n\nFox is treating the event like it would a World Series game, with its lead announcers set to call the game: Joe Davis (play-by-play) and John Smoltz (commentary). It also has its postseason pregame show crew on hand: Kevin Burkhardt as the host with commentary from Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz.\n\nOscar- and Grammy-winning artist Jon Batiste is to present a pregame musical tribute to the Negro Leagues, in which approximately 60 of its former players are scheduled to be on the field at approximately 6 p.m. Then the ceremonial first pitch is to be delivered by Bill Greason, a 99-year-old Negro Leagues alumnus who in 1954 was the Cardinals' first Black pitcher. He since has been a pastor in Birmingham.\n\nThe Cardinals and Giants will be wearing throwback uniforms representing Negro League teams that played in their cities -- the St. Louis Stars and the San Francisco Sea Lions.\n\nIt sets up for a memorable night.\n\n'Spectacular' look\n\n\"It's going to look spectacular\" on TV, Fox Sports Vice President of Field Operations and Engineering Brad Cheney told the Post-Dispatch, adding that the network will unfurl \"postseason technology\" for the telecast.\n\nTo that end, more than 20 cameras and in excess of 45 microphones will be positioned throughout the ballpark that will have a seating capacity of about 8,300 for the contest.\n\n\"Small stadiums have different sound\" than big league facilities, Cheney said, so Fox wants to relay that.\n\nThe production folks also are eager to show shots of players and plays that will be tighter in the quaint setting compared to an MLB stadium.\n\n\"We'll be close to the players,\" he said.\n\nThis event long has been on the drawing board, with talks beginning three years ago. Cheney said Fox officials made six trips to the facility from the start of the planning stages through the period when modifications were being made to the ballpark to accommodate the network's production as well as a big league game. He estimates that more than 12,000 man-hours have been spread across 270 people \"to bring this event to life.\"\n\nFox and MLB have tried to not be too disruptive. Despite the construction, Cheney said people who attended a game at Rickwood before the updates began should not notice any difference when looking at the field on Thursday. There was a minor league game played there Tuesday, giving organizers a couple of days to take care of any unexpected problems that arose before the main event arrives.\n\n\"It's been a very big undertaking,\" Cheney said, adding that he has been on-site since Friday. \"It's a large departure from normal, creating an event from the ground up.\"\n\nFox has had experience on the baseball front with starting from scratch, having televised games from the \"Field of Dreams\" in Dyersville, Iowa, in 2021 and '22. That was the setting of the 1989 film by that name.\n\nThat experience helps, but there also is a caveat.\n\n\"More challenging is that the stadium is here,\" he said. \"With the 'Field of Dreams,' we built the stadium from the ground up\" to its own specifications.\n\nDan Caesar - 314-340-8175\n\n@caesardan on X (formerly Twitter)\n\ndcaesar@post-dispatch.com\n\nLocations Stlouis Be the first to As such, many of baseball's greats have passed through: 181 future Hall of Famers, from Willie Mays to Jackie Robinson to Hank Aaron to Babe Ruth, played at the field.\n\nNow, a new group of players are set to join that list. Extensive renovations have prepped the ballpark for the modern game, with Thursday's clash to be held in front of a crowd of roughly 8,300.\n\nThe teams will also don commemorative throwback uniforms, an homage to the history of the Negro Leagues in St. Louis and San Francisco. In fact, all 157 living Negro League players have been invited to Thursday's game, with 60 confirmed to be attending.\n\nHere is everything that you need to know about watching Giants vs. Cardinals at historic Rickwood Field.\n\nGiants vs. Cardinals at Rickwood Field will air nationally on Fox, with Joe Davis (play-by-play), John Smoltz (color analyst), Ken Rosenthal (reporter), and Tom Verducci (reporter) expected to have the call.\n\nFans can also stream the game on Fubo, which offers a free trial.
