{"uri": "8187277239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:14:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:14:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:12:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb-integrated-negro-leagues-stats-150040424.html", "title": "MLB has integrated Negro Leagues stats. Is it too little, too late?", "body": "As Bob Kendrick, president of the Kansas City-based Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, tells it, baseball's all-time hit king had eyes like Ted Williams and power like Babe Ruth.\n\n\"For me, his greatest feat of all is hitting a ball into the right-field upper deck at Yankee Stadium,\" says Kendrick. \"They say he was circling the bases and just giggling. He was the kind of guy who was so strong that he could poke you in the arm and it would hurt, but he didn't know he was hurting you.\"\n\nThe indomitable Josh Gibson, nicknamed the Black Babe Ruth, managed all this while swinging a bat that measured 40 ounces and 41 inches - about 25% bigger than today's big leagues bats. \"You got to be a man,\" adds Kendrick, \"to swing that kind of lumber.\"\n\nOfficially, Gibson is now the man, after Major League Baseball announced the incorporation of records from the Negro Leagues, even though he never had an at-bat in the majors. The decision late last month to include more than 2,300 players followed a three-year research project, led by a special committee of Negro Leagues experts and statisticians.\n\nRelated: Willie Mays, baseball's towering legend and all-time Giants great, dies aged 93\n\nMLB's new stats database will formally launch before a special tribute game between the St Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday at Alabama's Rickwood Field, home to the Birmingham Black Barons, the team that launched Willie Mays, perhaps the finest player to ever pick up a bat and glove. Until his death on Tuesday at age 93, Mays - AKA the \"Say Hey Kid\" - was one of three surviving Negro Leagues players and baseball's oldest living Hall of Famer. MLB had already planned to pay special tribute Mays at a Negro Leagues commemorative game in absentia.\n\nMLB's statistical integration rights a wrong that had endured since Major League Baseball accepted Black players into its ranks in 1947, precipitating the Negro Leagues' slow death the next year. Why it took nearly 80 years to integrate the stats is a matter of ongoing controversy, with critics accusing MLB of going woke, and some Black baseball fans feeling it all comes far too late in the day. Nevertheless, 77 years since he last swung his bat, Gibson, an imposing catcher and slugger once relegated to the shadows, now stands above the rest.\n\nA gentle giant who loomed large behind the plate, whether crouched in front of the umpire or rolling up his sleeves to show off his massive biceps, Gibson overtook Ty Cobb in career batting average, surpassed Ruth in on-base plus slugging (a prominent advanced stat that measures a hitter's ability to reach base and hit for average and power), and topped Barry Bonds's single-season slugging percentage record, in two different years.\n\nNo US sport is more serious about its stats than baseball. Learned fans call up the most hallowed marks - Hank Aaron's 755 home runs, Pete Rose's 4,256 hits, Bob Gibson's 1.12 earned run average (ERA), Mays's 660 homers, 339 steals and 7,769 putouts (from centerfield!) - as easily as their own phone numbers. Statistics for Negro Leagues players were just as painstakingly kept among teams and the Black press, which was no mean feat in a league where no set schedule was guaranteed to play out as planned.\n\n\"They had to scramble to keep afloat,\" says John Thorn, the MLB house historian who chaired the 17-person committee that decided baseball's stat integration. \"If they played two or three games in a day and one was a league game and two were against integrated semi-pros, well, it was a paycheck.\" Negro Leagues players barnstormed the country to make ends meet. They were forced into that hustle, adds Thorn, because of \"MLB's racism\".\n\nRelated: 'A story that didn't used to be told': the rise and fall of baseball's Negro Leagues\n\nA 1969 committee on baseball records recognized six major leagues dating to 1876 - but excluded the Negro Leagues \"for no reason\", Thorn says. \"But while settling on those defunct rival leagues as equivalent of the major leagues, the subject of the Negro Leagues' caliber of play was not really much of a question. Everyone agreed it was pretty darn good. That's why I've taken to use the trope of Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man to describe the attitude toward Black baseball. It wasn't so much racist animus as it was the feeling that they weren't there.\"\n\nThe Negro Leagues weren't just an alternative pastime born from the two Americas that sprang up from segregation. As Sam Pollard shows in his 2023 documentary The League, the Negro Leagues teams were obvious indicators of thriving Black enclaves in major American cities. \"We couldn't go to major league games,\" Pollard told me, \"and if we did, we had to sit isolated, segregated from white audiences. So we created our own Black baseball teams, and that kept money circulating within our stores and funeral homes and the like, helping the community survive.\"\n\nIt wasn't until 2020, when Covid restrictions forced MLB to cut its schedule from 162 games to 60 (the baseline for an average Negro National League season) while making clear that the records generated during that span would be treated the same, that the league announced the integration of Negro League stats to correct \"a longtime oversight\". Over the course of six meetings, Thorn's MLB committee - which included representatives from the Negro Leagues database Seamheads, the MLB play-by-play archive Retrosheet and the Elias Sports Bureau, MLB's official record keeper - pored over decades' worth of game stories and box scores, separating out the inconsistencies among the stats (incongruent wins and losses) and stars (distinguishing among multiple players with the same name).\n\n\"In the end, once we acknowledged that a 60- to 80-game schedule may have been most frequent for Negro Leagues teams, we were able to empty a sliding, variable scale so that although the number of league-scheduled games per league, per team, per annum varied from year to year, what was constant is 3.1 plate appearances per scheduled game (to qualify for batting stats) and one inning pitched per scheduled game to qualify for ERA. Now the very same standards we used for white players we use for Black ones.\"\n\nThorn says the current analysis isn't the final word: \"There will be a version 2.0, and it will be richer than what we have today.\" Still, as overdue as these gestures are, there remains a contingency of Black baseball fans who feel as if this is too little, too late. Baseball stats have already been devalued after a number of players, including some Black players such as Bonds and Sammy Sosa, had their record-setting accomplishments invalidated during baseball's steroid era.\n\nMLB's nod to the Negro Leagues comes as Black American representation in the major leagues is at a historically low ebb. A USA Today study found that 5.7% of players were Black Americans, the lowest percentage since 1955, and that five teams didn't have any Black players. David Justice, a former all-star and World Series champion with the Atlanta Braves, chalks a lot of that up to the high cost of entry.\n\n\"There's this thing called [youth] travel ball,\" Justice explained to Fox Sports' Keyshawn Johnson, a former NFL star who started out playing baseball, \"and it costs a lot of money. A [proper] baseball bat costs $400. And if you don't have the family, you don't have the money. But I can go out here and grab that basketball, and we can go hoop all day.\" Nevertheless, diversity has increased across the league, with Latino representation shooting up from a handful of players in 1948 to nearly 30% of players by opening day 2024.\n\nThe hope is that by finally integrating Gibson and other Negro Leaguers like Buck O'Neil (a Negro Leagues all-star first baseman turned MLB scout and coach) and Norman \"Turkey\" Stearnes (so nicknamed for his waddly flair for rounding the bases) into the official record, fans will connect with this hidden history and fall deeper in love with the game.\n\nSadly, Gibson, the second Black player inducted into baseball's hall of fame, died of a brain tumor-induced stroke at age 35, months before Jackie Robinson broke MLB's color line in 1947. When longtime followers of Black baseball say there were far more talented players in the Negro Leagues than Robinson who could've made that same history, Gibson's name usually comes up first. (Thorn says Branch Rickey, the visionary Dodgers general manager who brought Robinson in, \"wanted someone with a college education\", believing Robinson's years at the University of California at Los Angeles had better prepared him for white society.)\n\nYet in the mind of many baseball fans, Robinson and Gibson don't compare because Gibson, despite stronger numbers, never crossed over to MLB. To Kendrick, that's a bad-faith premise. \"Someone on social media hit me and said: 'Well, we just want to compare apples to apples,'\" says Kendrick. \"No major leaguer ever had to go through what these players in the Negro Leagues had to endure. Never had to worry about where they were going to get a meal, go to sleep. Never had to eat peanut butter and crackers on the bus, or get dressed underneath the stands because they couldn't use the facility in the ballpark, couldn't wash their uniforms. So it can never be apples to apples.\"\n\nFor Cindy Cobb, Ty's granddaughter, the record is straight. \"I envision Turkey and Ty playing together in the outfield,\" Cobb told ESPN. \"Let's never use the color of skin to separate people.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187423619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:55:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.mlb.com/news/featured/rickwood-field-road-trip-part-1", "title": "Rickwood Field Road Trip Part 1", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - When the Negro Leagues Statistical Review Committee - containing baseball historians and journalists as well as former executives and players - released its findings last month that led to the incorporation of Negro Leagues stats into the Major League database, it made sure to highlight how fans should look at the history books.\n\n\"By realizing that statistics are shorthand for stories, that history is not product but process, and that the reasons for the very existence of the Negro Leagues are worthy of our study.\"\n\nBut the history of baseball is not told by statistics alone. It is told by ballparks. It is told by bats and balls and gloves and cleats and hats and uniforms. First and foremost, it is told by people.\n\nBirmingham's Rickwood Field - the oldest professional baseball stadium in America, standing since 1910, and the former home of the Negro American League's Birmingham Black Barons - is hosting Minor League Baseball and Major League Baseball games this week, and on the way to the hallowed ground, MLB Pipeline took a road trip through Florida and Alabama {"uri": "8185976414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:33:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:33:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:32:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/professional/mlb/cardinals/masyn-winn-embraces-opportunity-to-represent-black-community-at-rickwood-cardinals-extra/article_0d89ae64-2e41-11ef-871c-cb538e0079f5.html", "title": "Masyn Winn embraces opportunity to represent Black community at Rickwood: Cardinals Extra", "body": "MIAMI -- When the Cardinals rookie shortstop Masyn Winn and the rest of his teammates take the field Thursday night wearing St. Louis Stars throwback uniforms, it won't be the first time Winn has worn a uniform that paid homage to the legacy of the Negro Leagues.\n\nWinn, a Texas native and former second-round draft pick (54th overall in 2020), began play Wednesday leading all MLB rookies in batting average (.295) and ranked among the rookie leaders in on-base percentage (.339, second), hits (66, second), doubles (12, tied for third), and triples (three, tied for second). He also leads all major league shortstops in defensive runs saved (seven).\n\nLong before Cardinals fans knew about the 5-foot-10, right-handed-hitting shortstop with such a flamethrower arm that he was a two-way draft prospect and a highly regarded prep pitcher, he played on a the Houston-based Negro League Legends amateur team.\n\nInvestigator tracked Kim Gardner to health clinic as St. Louis prosecutor's office crashed Here are 13 must-visit restaurants in the St. Louis area from Ian Froeb's newsletter New Channel 32? Established stations 11, 5, BSM? Sports TV intrigue continues: Media Views UFL officials say they expect to grow after inaugural season, capped by Birmingham's title The 'Bad Dad Joke House' brings laughter to St. Louis Hazelwood woman killed by tree branch in trimming accident Cardinals broadcaster Bally Sports 'stuck in the middle' in dispute over contracts Police shoot, kill teen they say led them on chase and pointed gun in north St. Louis BenFred: The Cubs can't seem to let go of Cardinals catcher Willson Contreras Tickets as low as $4 for UFL's championship game in St. Louis St. Louis selected as potential 'home away from home' for World Cup teams in 2026 A sneak peek at St. Louis Zoo's new park, where animals are already busy Sam Page offered job to St. Louis County council candidate, asked her to weigh quitting race St. Louis to pay homeless to clean streets and pick up trash Aveda to close its Galleria store in Richmond Heights\n\nOn Thursday night, the Cardinals and San Francisco Giants face off in Birmingham, Alabama, in Major League Baseball's showcase event \"MLB at Rickwood Field.\" The oldest professional ballpark in the United States, Rickwood Field will host the event in celebration and recognition of the history of Black baseball on the day after the Juneteenth national holiday.\n\n\"Me and my stepdad have been talking about it since spring training,\" Winn said over the weekend.\n\nRickwood Field served as the home of the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues. Originally established as the Birmingham Stars in 1920 as one of the first eight teams of the Negro Southern League, they changed their name to the Black Barons. The club joined the Negro National League as an associate member in 1923 and a full member in 1925.\n\nAlabama native and Baseball Hall of Famer Willie Mays began his professional career as a teenager with the Black Barons in 1948. Mays, a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015, died Tuesday afternoon at the age of 93.\n\nSome of the other prominent players to wear Black Barons uniforms include Hall of Fame pitcher Satchel Paige and Hall of Fame slugger Mules Suttles.\n\nWinn was 8 years old when his stepfather, Earl Luckett, entered his life. Luckett, who had stint in minor league baseball in the Houston Astros organization in the 1980s, coached and ran amateur baseball teams.\n\n\"We'd wear a different last name on our back every weekend of somebody that played in the Negro League,\" Winn said. \"So for him, it's going to be super-special. For me, it's going to be super-special. Just getting to represent the Black community is going to be pretty cool.\"\n\nLuckett made his players learn about each of the players whose names were on the back of their jerseys. Players were required to research that player, put together a report and then present that report to the team.\n\n\"Let's say I was wearing Cool Papa Bell that weekend,\" Winn explained, \"Saturday we'd play, and Saturday night, we'd have to write up a little report. Sunday, we'd have to come and present to the whole team, giving some notes on them and some fun facts about the guys.\"\n\nThe part of the experience that stuck with Winn the most wasn't researching former players. It's the way Luckett made it a point to make baseball available to young Black players who might not have been able to play on travel teams or select squads.\n\n\"A lot of the kids on that team couldn't afford to do some stuff, so my stepdad would sponsor and bring them out,\" Winn said. \"I think just as a collective group, it was pretty good for a lot of those kids, just being able to play baseball with a lot of brothers. For the most part, you don't really see a lot of teams with Black players. To have a full team of Black players and just being able to be around the guys, I think that sticks with me the most. Just the kind of the impact that he had on us.\"\n\nWillie McGee on Willie Mays\n\nCardinals Hall of Famer and coach Willie McGee was born in San Francisco and grew up in the Bay Area when Mays was in the middle of a legendary career with the Giants following their move from New York to San Francisco.\n\nMays earned two National League MVP awards, 12 Gold Gloves, 24 All-Star selections, a batting title and the Rookie of the Year Award in 1951. Mays hit 660 home runs, stole 339 bases and posted a career batting average of .301.\n\nMcGee, a speedy outfielder who won an NL MVP, earned four All-Star selections, three Gold Gloves, a Silver Slugger and a World Series championship, spoke about Mays with great reverence prior to Wednesday's game.\n\n\"He was the greatest player that I ever saw,\" McGee said. \"I always say that he had a sixth tool, the hustle, the aggressiveness and the instincts, especially the way he ran the bases and played defense. There's not many guys who played like that.\"\n\nMcGee, 65, played for the Giants from 1991 to 94. Being a member of the Giants and a native of the Bay area gave McGee the chance to meet and interact with Mays in the middle of his own major league career.\n\nMcGee described Mays as \"fun-loving\" as well as \"humble\" and \"down to earth.\"\n\n\"It was humbling to see that this great player, great guy, one of the greatest players in the world in my book, for him to be the type of person that he was,\" McGee said. \"Most people are better people than they are players, but I can't say that about him. He was so good of a player and a great person. I was thinking about that last night.\"\n\nMcGee was 10 years into his 18-year major league career when he got to San Francisco, but he said he wished he'd been around Mays earlier in his career and been able to pick up even more from Mays.\n\nMcGee still recalls Mays telling and showing him how he didn't stuff his entire hand all the way in his glove. He simply used the pinky finger and thumb to close the glove around the baseball.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": {"uri": "8187560553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:44:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://spokesman-recorder.com/2024/06/20/mlb-negro-leagues-tribute/", "title": "Negro Leagues finally embraced as part of MLB history | Minnesota Spokesman-Recorder", "body": "On Thursday, June 20, MLB will play tribute to the Negro Leagues in a regular season game between San Francisco and St. Louis at Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Alabama. The ballpark, formerly the home of the Birmingham Black Barons, is considered the oldest professional ballpark in the U.S.\n\nThursday's game is the culmination of week-long events that began with a Monday screening and discussion of \"Say Hey, Willie Mays!\" an HBO documentary that chronicles the life and career of baseball legend Willie Mays. (The movie screening was planned before Mays' passing on June 18).\n\nOther events include local youth playing baseball at Regions Field, where the minor league Birmingham Barons play; a Wednesday luncheon honoring Negro Leagues families; and other community engagement events around the city.\n\nAlthough it was announced last year during the NABJ annual convention held in Birmingham, Thursday's game also will have added significance as it comes almost two months after MLB announced that Negro Leagues statistics will officially become part of its historical record, elevating them finally to major league status.\n\nMays, Jackie Robinson, Larry Doby, and Henry Aaron all once played in the Negro Leagues before baseball's integration in 1947. Now their stats will be integrated and updated: Mays' hit total is now 3,293, up 10 from his 1948 season in Birmingham. Robinson's 49 hits with Kansas City raise his total to 1,567. Satchel Paige's win total is now 125 with his 28 Negro Leagues victories.\n\nNegro Leaguer and Baseball Hall of Famer Josh Gibson now is MLB's single-season record holder in batting average (.466 in 1943), slugging percentage (.974 in 1937), and OPS (1.474 in 1937). His career slugging percentage (.718) and OPS (1.177) now surpass Babe Ruth in both categories.\n\nMore than 2,300 players who played in the Negro Leagues from 1920 through 1948 will be integrated into MLB's database. More statistics will continue to be revised and updated as more data and information is uncovered, say MLB officials.\n\n\"I think it's definitely way overdue and something that should have been done a long time ago,\" retired major leaguer Denard Span told the MSR. \"Those numbers and those players are being recognized and acknowledged. I think it's definitely a step in the right direction.\"\n\nSpan played 11 seasons in the majors -- the Twins drafted him in the first round (20 overall) in 2002 out of high school. He played five seasons in Minnesota (2008-12), then Washington (2013-15), San Francisco (2016-17), Tampa Bay and Seattle (2018). He retired from baseball in June 2020.\n\nAfter working for his hometown Tampa Bay Rays television broadcast team in 2023, Span joined the Twins television team this season as an analyst.\n\n\"It came about over the last couple of years\" when he filled in whenever absences occurred during Twins broadcasts, recalls Span. \"It was the right time where everything was able to align, and that's kind of how it materialized in a nutshell.\"\n\nOther than being scheduled to work a home series in late July, Span will mostly work Twins road games. \"I'm new to this,\" he admitted. [Former teammate and current Twins special assistant and television broadcaster] LaTroy Hawkins has been doing it a lot longer than me.\"\n\nAlthough he has yet to perfect his broadcast on-air style, \"I tried to keep it as simple as possible,\" said Span. He and Hawkins, along with MLB execs Tony Reagins and Tyrone Brooks, will be featured on a panel discussion at the July 31 Minnesota Twins' 13 annual Diversity Celebration at the team's ballpark.\n\nSpan also works with other former MLBers to attract more Blacks to baseball. \"I try to talk about the pros, about playing the game of baseball, and about all of the blessings that it brought to me and my families...and how beautiful of a game it is,\" he said proudly.\n\n\"I played basketball and football as well. I just try to encourage and encourage them and tell them honestly baseball has been good to me.\"", "source": {"uri": "spokesman-recorder.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Minnesota "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-20", "textStart": 13, "textEnd": 20}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-18", "textStart": 568, "textEnd": 575}, {"amb": "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187266470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:06:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:06:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jun/20/negro-baseball-leagues-mlb-stats-integration", "title": "MLB has integrated Negro Leagues stats. Is it too little, too late?", "body": "Josh Gibson, nicknamed the Black Babe Ruth, is belatedly recognized as the all-time hit king and a tribute game will be held in Alabama today - but only 5.7% of players are now Black\n\nAs Bob Kendrick, president of the Kansas City-based Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, tells it, baseball's all-time hit king had eyes like Ted Williams and power like Babe Ruth.\n\n\"For me, his greatest feat of all is hitting a ball into the right-field upper deck at Yankee Stadium,\" says Kendrick. \"They say he was circling the bases and just giggling. He was the kind of guy who was so strong that he could poke you in the arm and it would hurt, but he didn't know he was hurting you.\"\n\nThe indomitable Josh Gibson, nicknamed the Black Babe Ruth, managed all this while swinging a bat that measured 40 ounces and 41 inches - about 25% bigger than today's big leagues bats. \"You got to be a man,\" adds Kendrick, \"to swing that kind of lumber.\"\n\nOfficially, Gibson is now the man, after Major League Baseball announced the incorporation of records from the Negro Leagues, even though he never had an at-bat in the majors. The decision late last month to include more than 2,300 players followed a three-year research project, led by a special committee of Negro Leagues experts and statisticians.\n\nMLB's new stats database will formally launch before a special tribute game between the St Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants on Thursday at Alabama's Rickwood Field, home to the Birmingham Black Barons, the team that launched Willie Mays, perhaps the finest player to ever pick up a bat and glove. Until his death on Tuesday at age 93, Mays - AKA the \"Say Hey Kid\" - was one of three surviving Negro Leagues players and baseball's oldest living Hall of Famer. MLB had already planned to pay special tribute Mays at a Negro Leagues commemorative game in absentia.\n\nMLB's statistical integration rights a wrong that had endured since Major League Baseball accepted Black players into its ranks in 1947, precipitating the Negro Leagues' slow death the next year. Why it took nearly 80 years to integrate the stats is a matter of ongoing controversy, with critics accusing MLB of going woke, and some Black baseball fans feeling it all comes far too late in the day. Nevertheless, 77 years since he last swung his bat, Gibson, an imposing catcher and slugger once relegated to the shadows, now stands above the rest.\n\nA gentle giant who loomed large behind the plate, whether crouched in front of the umpire or rolling up his sleeves to show off his massive biceps, Gibson overtook Ty Cobb in career batting average, surpassed Ruth in on-base plus slugging (a prominent advanced stat that measures a hitter's ability to reach base and hit for average and power), and topped Barry Bonds's single-season slugging percentage record, in two different years.\n\nNo US sport is more serious about its stats than baseball. Learned fans call up the most hallowed marks - Hank Aaron's 755 home runs, Pete Rose's 4,256 hits, Bob Gibson's 1.12 earned run average (ERA), Mays's 660 homers, 339 steals and 7,769 putouts (from centerfield!) - as easily as their own phone numbers. Statistics for Negro Leagues players were just as painstakingly kept among teams and the Black press, which was no mean feat in a league where no set schedule was guaranteed to play out as planned.\n\n\"They had to scramble to keep afloat,\" says John Thorn, the MLB house historian who chaired the 17-person committee that decided baseball's stat integration. \"If they played two or three games in a day and one was a league game and two were against integrated semi-pros, well, it was a paycheck.\" Negro Leagues players barnstormed the country to make ends meet. They were forced into that hustle, adds Thorn, because of \"MLB's racism\".\n\nA 1969 committee on baseball records recognized six major leagues dating to 1876 - but excluded the Negro Leagues \"for no reason\", Thorn says. \"But while settling on those defunct rival leagues as equivalent of the major leagues, the subject of the Negro Leagues' caliber of play was not really much of a question. Everyone agreed it was pretty darn good. That's why I've taken to use the trope of Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man to describe the attitude toward Black baseball. It wasn't so much racist animus as it was the feeling that they weren't there.\"\n\nThe Negro Leagues weren't just an alternative pastime born from the two Americas that sprang up from segregation. As Sam Pollard shows in his 2023 documentary The League, the Negro Leagues teams were obvious indicators of thriving Black enclaves in major American cities. \"We couldn't go to major league games,\" Pollard told me, \"and if we did, we had to sit isolated, segregated from white audiences. So we created our own Black baseball teams, and that kept money circulating within our stores and funeral homes and the like, helping the community survive.\"\n\nIt wasn't until 2020, when Covid restrictions forced MLB to cut its schedule from 162 games to 60 (the baseline for an average Negro National League season) while making clear that the records generated during that span would be treated the same, that the league announced the integration of Negro League stats to correct \"a longtime oversight\". Over the course of six meetings, Thorn's MLB committee - which included representatives from the Negro Leagues database Seamheads, the MLB play-by-play archive Retrosheet and the Elias Sports Bureau, MLB's official record keeper - pored over decades' worth of game stories and box scores, separating out the inconsistencies among the stats (incongruent wins and losses) and stars (distinguishing among multiple players with the same name).\n\n\"In the end, once we acknowledged that a 60- to 80-game schedule may have been most frequent for Negro Leagues teams, we were able to empty a sliding, variable scale so that although the number of league-scheduled games per league, per team, per annum varied from year to year, what was constant is 3.1 plate appearances per scheduled game (to qualify for batting stats) and one inning pitched per scheduled game to qualify for ERA. Now the very same standards we used for white players we use for Black ones.\"\n\nThorn says the current analysis isn't the final word: \"There will be a version 2.0, and it will be richer than what we have today.\" Still, as overdue as these gestures are, there remains a contingency of Black baseball fans who feel as if this is too little, too late. Baseball stats have already been devalued after a number of players, including some Black players such as Bonds and Sammy Sosa, had their record-setting accomplishments invalidated during baseball's steroid era.\n\nMLB's nod to the Negro Leagues comes as Black American representation in the major leagues is at a historically low ebb. A USA Today study found that 5.7% of players were Black, the lowest percentage since 1955, and that five teams didn't have any Black players. David Justice, a former all-star and World Series champion with the Atlanta Braves, chalks a lot of that up to the high cost of entry.\n\n\"There's this thing called [youth] travel ball,\" Justice explained to Fox Sports' Keyshawn Johnson, a former NFL star who started out playing baseball, \"and it costs a lot of money. A [proper] baseball bat costs $400. And if you don't have the family, you don't have the money. But I can go out here and grab that basketball, and we can go hoop all day.\" Nevertheless, diversity has increased across the league, with Latino representation shooting up from a handful of players in 1948 to nearly 30% of players by opening day 2024.\n\nThe hope is that by finally integrating Gibson and other Negro Leaguers like Buck O'Neil (a Negro Leagues all-star first baseman turned MLB scout and coach) and Norman \"Turkey\" Stearnes (so nicknamed for his waddly flair for rounding the bases) into the official record, fans will connect with this hidden history and fall deeper in love with the game.\n\nSadly, Gibson, the second Black player inducted into baseball's hall of fame, died of a brain tumor-induced stroke at age 35, months before Jackie Robinson broke MLB's color line in 1947. When longtime followers of Black baseball say there were far more talented players in the Negro Leagues than Robinson who could've made that same history, Gibson's name usually comes up first. (Thorn says Branch Rickey, the visionary Dodgers general manager who brought Robinson in, \"wanted someone with a college education\", believing Robinson's years at the University of California at Los Angeles had better prepared him for white society.)\n\nYet in the mind of many baseball fans, Robinson and Gibson don't compare because Gibson, despite stronger numbers, never crossed over to MLB. To Kendrick, that's a bad-faith premise. \"Someone on social media hit me and said: 'Well, we just want to compare apples to apples,'\" says Kendrick. \"No major leaguer ever had to go through what these players in the Negro Leagues had to endure. Never had to worry about where they were going to get a meal, go to sleep. Never had to eat peanut butter and crackers on the bus, or get dressed underneath the stands because they couldn't use the facility in the ballpark, couldn't wash their uniforms. So it can never be apples to apples.\"\n\nFor Cindy Cobb, Ty's granddaughter, the record is straight. \"I envision Turkey and Ty playing together in the outfield,\" Cobb told ESPN. \"Let's never use the color of skin to separate people.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "andrew_lawrence@theguardian.com", "name": "Andrew {"uri": "2024-06-395729686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:13:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:13:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:35:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.aol.com/rickwood-field-renovated-historic-mlb-093522547.html", "title": "How Rickwood Field was renovated for historic MLB game: 'We maintained the magic'", "body": "How Rickwood Field was renovated for historic MLB game: 'We maintained the magic'\n\nJoe Mock\n\nJune 20, 2024 at 11:35 AM\n\nThe year was 1992, the 82nd anniversary of the opening of Rickwood Field. But there was no birthday celebration.\n\nIt had been five years since the Birmingham Barons of the Southern League had moved out, preferring the modern amenities of a brand-new ballpark in the southern suburb of Hoover. With no tenant, local residents who'd grown up attending games - both of the Barons in the white minor leagues and the Black Barons in the Negro leagues - had a legitimate fear that Rickwood would be demolished.\n\n\"Birmingham had a great old building that was our terminal station for rail and bus travelers. It was a beautiful piece of art, but it was torn down in 1976,\" recalls Gerald Watkins, the chairman of the board of the Friends of Rickwood, the non-profit tasked with preserving the ballpark. \"Some of us were old enough to remember the terminal going away, and we thought we didn't want to see this old ballpark go away the same way.\"\n\nThe facility had fallen into disrepair by 1992. When an advance crew from Hollywood came on a rainy night to check out the site for possible use in a movie, there was nowhere for them to meet in the grandstands. That's because water was pouring through the leaky roof everywhere they tried to gather.\n\nWith the aging park falling apart, Watkins feels this was the darkest point in Rickwood's history.\n\nBut the filmmakers decided the vintage look of the park was perfect for their bio-pic of Ty Cobb. After all, Cobb was playing for the Detroit Tigers when Rickwood was built in 1910.\n\n\"The city mobilized. Big companies in town mobilized. The Friends of Rickwood were formed, and enough money was raised to get the ballpark brought to a level where the film could be done,\" says Watkins. The film \"Cobb,\" starring Tommy Lee Jones in the title role, opened in 1994.\n\n\"That movie was the first inning of the rebirth of Rickwood,\" Watkins says.\n\nHe admits that since the work done for \"Cobb,\" \"It's been very hard to get any big money to do the repairs that were needed.\" Now the impending arrival of Major League Baseball for a game is giving this historic park another lease on life.\n\nThe San Francisco Giants will facethe St. Louis Cardinals in a regular-season game at Rickwood on June 20. Fox will handle the nationwide broadcast (7:15 ET) of the sold-out contest.\n\nMaintaining the magic\n\nBefore MLB decided to bring a game to Rickwood, it sent their advance team in the winter of 2022 to see if it would be feasible. After all, the structure and playing field had been around for 112 years.\n\nMurray Cook of Brightview has been MLB's main field consultant since 1993, when he prepared ballfields in Eastern Europe for a series of games by U.S. minor leaguers. The visit to Rickwood a year-and-a-half ago marked the first time he'd seen the wooden ballpark.\n\n\"It brought back memories of some of the old stadiums I'd worked in over the years,\" he recalls. \"It is a really unique, cool place.\"\n\nDespite that aura, the playing surface \"was basically a rec-level field. It was in really poor condition. It was some weeds, some grass, some Bermuda (grass), some more weeds. And the dugouts were like bunkers. When you were standing in one, you couldn't see the left fielder because there was a big bump in the middle of the field.\"\n\nPerhaps the biggest anomalies were the foul lines.\n\n\"They'd been putting chalk down the foul lines for, what, 100 years,\" Cook says. \"This made the line literally a foot higher than the field on either side of it. We knew we were facing a challenge of building a new field that meets major league quality in an existing venue that wasn't designed to hold a regulation field.\"\n\nSo the first order of business was to excavate and remove the top two feet of the playing surface.\n\nA system of pipes was installed that could drain away rainwater at a rate of seven to 10 inches an hour. Above it, a layer of gravel was applied, then a blend of sand and dirt for the roots of the grass to grow into.\n\nThen bermuda-grass sod was meticulously rolled on top.\n\nCook's crew was also in charge of replacing the dugouts, the backstop, foul poles and the fencing around the field.\n\nBrightview also encountered two clashes of yesterday and today: The field needed netting all the way down the foul territory, very much unlike the screens of decades ago; and the existing light standards actually protruded from the top of the roof over the field.\n\n\"Those lights are part of the charm and history there, and we didn't want to take them down,\" Cooks says. \"We left the fixtures and took out the lenses and bulbs, so if a ball did hit them, you wouldn't have glass crashing onto a player.\"\n\nThe lighting for the MLB night game will come from temporary light standards, brought in on flatbed trucks.\n\n\"The big challenge with Rickwood was to ensure we maintained the magic and history of the venue,\" says Cook.\n\nCreating the pallet\n\nIn recent years, MLB has staged events in venues where none had existed previously. Examples include the pop-up ballpark built on an abandoned golf course at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in 2016 and the incredibly successful Field of Dreams games in the cornfield in Dyersville, Iowa, the past two years.\n\nRickwood Field presents unique challenges.\n\n\"We were handed a stadium that is very old and doesn't meet code in many ways,\" says Todd Barnes, principal at architecture firm Populous. \"We had to fit Major League Baseball into a place that was never intended to have it.\"\n\nThe park's tiny locker rooms and press box didn't come close to doing the job.\n\n\"Rickwood was never built in scale for any occupancy of this size,\" says Populous associate principal Michael Kinard. \"We have to provide almost all the facilities that are required for the event, from clubhouses to the operational area to media functions.\"\n\nWhat little parking had been adjacent to Rickwood is now occupied by a complex of temporary structures housing all of the functions needed to host a modern-day MLB contest. Fans will have to park at Legion Field a mile away and take shuttles to the ballpark.\n\n\"The goal was to take a very gentle touch to it,\" says Barnes. \"Obviously, we didn't want to overhaul a historic building.\"\n\nNo new structures were added. Instead, existing seats were removed to accommodate wheelchairs.\n\n\"We love these kinds of challenges and accept them with open arms. These are the best games for us overall,\" says Barnes. \"We're creating the pallet for MLB to frame the right game presentation to make it just an incredible day.\"\n\nJoe Mock covers sports facilities for USA TODAY publications\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: How Rickwood Field was renovated for historic MLB game", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8186933751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:39:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:39:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:38:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/tv/2024/06/how-to-watch-mlb-at-rickwood-field-san-francisco-giants-vs-st-louis-cardinals-channel-stream-preview.html", "title": "How to watch MLB at Rickwood Field - San Francisco Giants vs. St. Louis Cardinals | Channel, stream, preview", "body": "BIRMINGHAM, AL -- Baseball is returning to its roots on Thursday night, as Major League Baseball pays homage to the history of Rickwood Field, as the San Francisco Giants take on the St. Louis Cardinals.\n\nRickwood Field is the oldest existing professional ballpark in the nation. Opened in 1910, it has been the home to a variety of teams, most notably from the Negro Leagues. MLB legends like Dizzy Dean and others have graced its field, while Hall of Famers like the late Satchel Paige and Willie Mays played for the Birmingham Black Barons prior to becoming major-league greats.\n\nThe ballpark has been renovated to accompany the big-league scene, featuring two of the oldest teams in the league's history. The Cardinals are quietly pushing themselves back into playoff contention. With wins in six of their last 10 games, and an even 9-9 record in the month of June, they are up to second place in the National League Central, 7.5 games behind the Milwaukee Brewers for first place. However, the Redbirds hold onto the last Wild Card spot, a half-game ahead of the pack.\n\nThe Giants are one of those teams trying to chase down St. Louis. Despite having lost back-to-back games, San Francisco is just one game back of a Wild Card spot. They are fourth in the NL West, 9.5 behind the first-place Los Angeles Dodgers.\n\nThursday night marks the first of six games between the Cards and Giants.", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", Being here in Birmingham where he started his career ... I believe that his time in the Negro Leagues really helped him be a great major league baseball player.\"\n\nMays's legacy was on full display at the museum and his shadow loomed large over the day, whether as part of the exhibit honoring the 1948 Birmingham Black Barons, on a mural unveiled a few miles away or during a luncheon at the museum hosted by the Negro Leagues Family Alliance, a group of families of former players whose mission is to preserve the leagues' history and legacy. {"uri": "2024-06-396165183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:21:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:21:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:13:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.al.com/sports/2024/06/say-hey-tonight-we-are-all-team-rickwood-the-way-it-always-should-have-been.html", "title": "Say hey! Tonight we are all Team Rickwood, the way it always should have been.", "body": "Now you say it back, the way Willie Mays did as a young Buck in the big city, when he couldn't remember your name but didn't want to be impolite. Imagine. After all the names people who looked like him were called by people who didn't.\n\nThen he came along with his bat and his spikes, his glove and his arm, running out from under his hat, running down that line drive over his head, daring fear and ignorance to keep up. How could you hate a man with those skills and that smile?\n\nYou're here in large part because he's from here, and as the sign says, it's nice to have you in Birmingham. We wanted Willie to be here, too, to watch his San Francisco Giants play the St. Louis Cardinals at Rickwood Field to honor the Negro Leagues. It would have been a fitting last public act for the man who roamed center field at Rickwood for the Black Barons, who did the same for the Giants before and after they moved from New York to California.\n\nWe hoped he would feel fit enough at 93 to come home for one last thank you for something more important than the 3,292 hits, the 660 home runs, the 12 Gold Gloves, the first-ballot Hall of Fame selection and the inclusion on any credible short list of the greatest players ever.\n\nSay this the loudest about the Say Hey Kid: At a time when the whole world watched the worst of us, Willie Mays showed them our best.", "source": {"uri": "al.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "al"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kevin_scarbinsky@al.com", "name": "Kevin Scarbinsky", "type": "author", and Museum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_fielder", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Center fielder"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_run", "type": "wiki", "https://www.al.com/resizer/v2/JZ43VO5RBJDJFLHBOMRUYE3SX4.jpg?auth=bc296dddfc6944c4fbd818c8fd6137df5b61a8aff136c0c916592933c1ca46b8&width=1280&quality=90", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 131, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187015162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:28:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:28:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:27:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/06/17/rickwood-field-mlb-rebuild", "title": "Rickwood Field: If you rebuild it ...", "body": "When Major League Baseball debuted the Field of Dreams game in Iowa three years ago, it honored the mystical setting of a fictional movie. When the Cardinals and Giants play the first official regular-season game at Birmingham's Rickwood Field this week, it will honor the mythical reality of Negro Leagues legends and the ballpark dozens of them once roamed.\n\nBuilt in 1910, Rickwood Field is the oldest existing professional baseball stadium in the United States. It was a central setting for Negro Leagues games until the 1960s; the first minor league baseball stadium in the country with permanent lights for nighttime baseball; and a venue that hosted games featuring legends from Babe Ruth and Ted Williams to Mickey Mantle and Reggie Jackson.\n\n\"There is just so much history here,\" said Gerald Watkins, one of Rickwood Field's primary caretakers and a member of the Friends of Rickwood group, which helps operate the venue. \"It's a national treasure, and I'm glad we were able to get MLB to come here so the nation can know what we here locally have known for a long time.\"\n\nIt's largely thanks to Watkins that the Cardinals and Giants are coming to Rickwood. He had just retired from a career in banking in 2021 and volunteered to begin taking care of the old stadium full time when he saw MLB play at the Field of Dreams site. That was cool, Watkins thought, but based on a fictional movie. Wouldn't MLB want to play at a stadium with real history?\n\nHe reached out to MLB, which responded positively and promised to get back to him. The league did the next year, providing a list of all the work that would need to be done to the stadium -- the dugouts, for example, were built for the comparative Lilliputian ballplayers of the 1930s, not today's MLBehemoths, and the infield had a foot-and-a-half crown -- to make it suitable for a real MLB game.\n\n\"We were like the perfect storm for them,\" Watkins said. \"They saw a great opportunity here.\"\n\n\u25a0\u25a0\u25a0\u25a0\n\nTo determine just how much work it would take to bring that opportunity to life, BaAM Productions, MLB's right-hand firm for the one-off games that have become so popular during the last decade, in 2021 assessed the feasibility of hosting a game at Rickwood Field. Any such assessment must balance a site's potential for hosting high-level pro sports with the imaginative potential, said Shani Hamilton Greenlaw, who has overseen the project for BaAM.\n\nThe site -- the playing field especially -- had to be brought up to 2024 MLB levels. While BaAM would handle the historic look and feel of the event, Birmingham-based contractor A.G. Gaston handled design and renovation of the field, with BrightView's help.\n\n\"We knew we had some work to do,\" said Murray Cook, a 35-year MLB field and stadium consultant with commercial landscaping firm BrightView. \"The field was in pretty rough shape, the stadium needed some love, and the overall distances were a little skewed.\"\n\nThe city of Birmingham committed $4.5 million to the renovation, which began in October 2023. The foremost issue was the field's foot-and-a-half crown; a player standing in the original first-base dugout looking toward left field would only see the top half of the left fielder. The crowned surface was scraped off, with 4,000 tons of material removed to bring the playing field to grade. New drainage and sand were installed beneath a new grass surface.\n\nRickwood's unusually deep backstop area -- measuring 85 feet from home plate to the fence -- was a quirk appreciated by Bo Jackson, who played high school, college and minor league ball at the stadium and could routinely score from first on a catcher's passed ball. The backstop area was shortened to 60 feet, \"a change that I know a lot of people welcome,\" said Watkins.\n\nThe dugouts, so low that in recent years many players would sit on top of them during games, were replaced and the foul lines were dug up and relined; there was at least a foot-deep line of chalk, used for more than a hundred years to mark the foul lines for each game. New foul poles were also installed, a project that included replacing the right-field foul pole, which passed through the roof of the seating stand in that corner of the stadium.\n\nThe venue's funky dimensions -- roughly 478 feet to the concrete center-field wall; the deepest in MLB is Coors Field, at 415 -- were reshaped, resulting in 400 feet to center field, 370 to right field and 325 to left. The double-decker wall was kept, but padding added to its lower half.\n\nTemporary lighting from Musco Lighting will be used instead of the stadium's unique lighting structures. A media center, MLB-level clubhouses and locker rooms, and batting tunnels have been built adjacent to the old stadium. The stadium's seating stands, and iconic, nearly 100-year-old scoreboard remained largely untouched, though Fox broadcast positions have been scattered throughout. Engineering checks were conducted to ensure the ground could hold the weight of the new structures, and that the water, for example, was suitable for consumption.\n\nRickwood is more than just a nostalgic reminder of when baseball dominated the American sporting landscape. The venue remains in constant use and will continue to be, with its renovated field, after MLB leaves. The stadium is home to baseball teams from three Birmingham high schools and local HBCU Miles College, and serves as a mecca for youth travel baseball circuits; it hosts various travel tournaments on 18 of July's 31 days. The venue also has a steady private events business and has been used by the film industry as a historic baseball setting for movies like \"42,\" the 2013 film about Jackie Robinson integrating the major leagues. The interest in those will only increase following the MLB game.\n\nA big factor in how many private events and baseball tournaments are held at the stadium in the coming years will be how well the upgrades are maintained. MLB made it clear to Watkins and the Friends of Rickwood that if they wanted the league to come back and play another game at the stadium, they needed to take care of the changes. And, said Watkins, \"we desperately want MLB to come back a second time.\"\n\n\u25a0\u25a0\u25a0\u25a0\n\nFor this first game, the goal is \"vintage Rickwood will be the experience for everybody,\" according to BaAM President Annemarie Roe. With that in mind, the project team zeroed in on a look dating to the 1940s and '50s. BaAM, with the help of Populous, helped design and build the temporary plaza sitting between the ticketed entrance and the stadium's main entrance that will house MLB sponsor booths, interactive fan activities, Negro Leagues history graphic displays, an entertainment stage and an official MLB at Rickwood merchandise store. The historic clubhouses will be renovated and open for fans to tour.\n\nMLB Senior Creative Director Jason Yeadon was largely responsible for the details that create the aesthetic and design environment of the 1940s and '50s, arguably Rickwood Field's heyday. That work included creating a style guide that was referenced in all signage, wayfinding and sponsorship/advertising decisions, starting with the game's logo.\n\n\"We wanted to make sure we were pulling from an identity that felt like it was pulling from the Negro Leagues but that had a modern expression,\" he said, \"because this is a modern game.\"\n\nThe devotion to historical accuracy bled into sponsorship activations and signage. Major focus was devoted to making sure the sponsors' brands (colors, typography and voice) were authentic to the period and the event, especially if the brand existed between 1910 and 1950 (Budweiser, for example). Presentations were built out for roughly 15 sponsors to show how MLB would preserve the look of the outfield wall and how sponsors could turn their brand, logo and taglines vintage. Musco Lighting, for example, will have a retro, aged-looking sign on the outfield wall alluding to its part in baseball being played under the lights. Even the screws appending signage to buildings (and the outfield wall) are ones that could be found in the 1940s.\n\n\"From big to small,\" Yeadon said, \"all the details are going to make this feel like it's a game from that time.\"\n\nAll those small touches are likely to have a big effect at bringing to life the people and the moments that mark Rickwood's unique connection to the national pastime.\n\n\"The history is so palpable there,\" said Hamilton Greenlaw. \"I grew up as a baseball fan, my dad telling me about the Negro Leagues players and learning about Willie Mays and Satchel Paige, so knowing that they played there, it was amazing to be able to walk through that space and know that it had seen so many of baseball's most incredible players and has this history, just ... I actually got a little misty, to be honest.\"", "source": {"uri": "sportsbusinessjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "sportsbusinessjournal.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186786028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:09:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:09:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:08:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/news/michael-jordan-rickwood-field-minor-league-birmingham-barons/a65956893d6c18688a51fa14", "title": "Did Michael Jordan play at Rickwood Field? Revisiting NBA legend's minor-league career with Birmingham Barons", "body": "There have been some all-time famous players that have, at some point, played baseball in Birmingham.\n\nThe great Willie Mays began his professional baseball career with the Birmingham Black Barons. One of the greatest pitchers of all time, Satchel Paige, wore a Black Barons uniform as well. Rollie Fingers, Reggie Jackson, Frank Thomas, and several other future Hall of Famers came through the city as minor leaguers.\n\nOne such baseball player -- arguably more famous than all of them combined -- went on to play exactly zero games in the major leagues: Michael Jordan.\n\nConsidered by many the greatest basketball player of all time and perhaps the greatest athlete of all time, Jordan briefly left basketball to play baseball in 1994, signing with the Chicago White Sox and joining the organization's minor leagues.\n\nWhere was he assigned? That would be Birmingham, where he joined the franchise's Double-A affiliate.\n\nAs Major League Baseball prepares to head to Birmingham to play in Rickwood Field, the longtime home of the Negro League Birmingham Black Barons and at several points the home of the Barons, Sporting News is taking a look back at Jordan's baseball career in Birmingham.\n\nMORE: Revisiting Willie Mays' career, from Birmingham Black Barons to the Giants\n\nJordan missed playing at Rickwood Field by a few years.\n\nThe Barons played at Rickwood Field from 1910-87, with the only breaks coming during periods in which the team did not exist. The field was the home of the Black Barons from the first edition of the team in 1920 to the final disbanding of the organization in 1960, just over two years before Jordan was born.\n\nInstead, Jordan's lone season in the minors came in 1994, when the Double-A Barons played baseball at Hoover Metropolitan Stadium. The team moved to Regions Field in 2013.\n\nMORE: Was Michael Jordan good at baseball?\n\nJordan announced he would be retiring from basketball on Oct. 6, 1993. He later said the murder of his father during a carjacking was a contributing factor to the decision.\n\nHis father, James Jordan, was a baseball fan, and Michael played the sport when he was young. He wound up deciding he would give baseball a chance.\n\nJerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls, also owned the White Sox, which made the franchise a natural fit for Jordan. He had already taken batting practice at Comiskey Park and had previously mentioned interest in trying baseball.\n\nThe White Sox signed Jordan to a minor-league deal on Feb. 7, 1994, just before he turned 31. Jordan did not get off to a hot start in spring training, but late in the spring, he went 2-for-5 with a double in the Windy City Classic exhibition game at Wrigley Field.\n\n\"I don't think I've proven I can make the team,\" Jordan told writers that spring, as reported in TSN's Chicago White Sox team notes. \"That's just being honest. ... But I'm not going to give up. I'm trying to squeeze five years into eight weeks. It just hasn't happened the way I wanted it to.\"\n\nMORE: Photos from Michael Jordan's baseball career\n\nJordan did not make the big-league roster and was assigned to Double-A Birmingham. He debuted with Birmingham on April 8, 1994.\n\nThe NBA legend had a respectable campaign for the Barons, particularly for someone who hadn't played professional baseball before the season. He hit .202 with a .556 OPS and three home runs. He also swiped 30 bases, walked 41 times, and struck out 114 times in 127 games (497 plate appearances).\n\nJordan later went on to play in the Arizona Fall League after the season, hitting .252.\n\nJordan's manager, Terry Francona, who later went on to manage the Red Sox to a pair of World Series wins and Cleveland to a pennant, said he felt Jordan could have reached the majors had he had more playing time.\n\n\"I do think with another 1,000 at-bats, he would've made it,\" Francona said, per ESPN. \"But there's something else that people miss about that season. Baseball wasn't the only thing he picked up. I truly believe that he rediscovered himself, his joy for competition. We made him want to play basketball again.\"\n\nJordan did not wind up playing again in baseball. He returned to basketball after the season in Birmingham, ending his lone year in professional baseball.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, {"uri": "8186755043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:50:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:50:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:49:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/rickwood-field-renovated-historic-mlb-093522882.html", "title": "How Rickwood Field was renovated for historic MLB game: 'We maintained the magic'", "body": "The year was 1992, the 82nd anniversary of the opening of Rickwood Field. But there was no birthday celebration.\n\nIt had been five years since the Birmingham Barons of the Southern League had moved out, preferring the modern amenities of a brand-new ballpark in the southern suburb of Hoover. With no tenant, local residents who'd grown up attending games - both of the Barons in the white minor leagues and the Black Barons in the Negro leagues - had a legitimate fear that Rickwood would be demolished.\n\n\"Birmingham had a great old building that was our terminal station for rail and bus travelers. It was a beautiful piece of art, but it was torn down in 1976,\" recalls Gerald Watkins, the chairman of the board of the Friends of Rickwood, the non-profit tasked with preserving the ballpark. \"Some of us were old enough to remember the terminal going away, and we thought we didn't want to see this old ballpark go away the same way.\"\n\nThe facility had fallen into disrepair by 1992. When an advance crew from Hollywood came on a rainy night to check out the site for possible use in a movie, there was nowhere for them to meet in the grandstands. That's because water was pouring through the leaky roof everywhere they tried to gather.\n\nWith the aging park falling apart, Watkins feels this was the darkest point in Rickwood's history.\n\nBut the filmmakers decided the vintage look of the park was perfect for their bio-pic of Ty Cobb. After all, Cobb was playing for the Detroit Tigers when Rickwood was built in 1910.\n\n\"The city mobilized. Big companies in town mobilized. The Friends of Rickwood were formed, and enough money was raised to get the ballpark brought to a level where the film could be done,\" says Watkins. The film \"Cobb,\" starring Tommy Lee Jones in the title role, opened in 1994.\n\n\"That movie was the first inning of the rebirth of Rickwood,\" Watkins says.\n\nHe admits that since the work done for \"Cobb,\" \"It's been very hard to get any big money to do the repairs that were needed.\" Now the impending arrival of Major League Baseball for a game is giving this historic park another lease on life.\n\nThe San Francisco Giants will facethe St. Louis Cardinals in a regular-season game at Rickwood on June 20. Fox will handle the nationwide broadcast (7:15 ET) of the sold-out contest.\n\nBefore MLB decided to bring a game to Rickwood, it sent their advance team in the winter of 2022 to see if it would be feasible. After all, the structure and playing field had been around for 112 years.\n\nMurray Cook of Brightview has been MLB's main field consultant since 1993, when he prepared ballfields in Eastern Europe for a series of games by U.S. minor leaguers. The visit to Rickwood a year-and-a-half ago marked the first time he'd seen the wooden ballpark.\n\n\"It brought back memories of some of the old stadiums I'd worked in over the years,\" he recalls. \"It is a really unique, cool place.\"\n\nDespite that aura, the playing surface \"was basically a rec-level field. It was in really poor condition. It was some weeds, some grass, some Bermuda (grass), some more weeds. And the dugouts were like bunkers. When you were standing in one, you couldn't see the left fielder because there was a big bump in the middle of the field.\"\n\nPerhaps the biggest anomalies were the foul lines.\n\n\"They'd been putting chalk down the foul lines for, what, 100 years,\" Cook says. \"This made the line literally a foot higher than the field on either side of it. We knew we were facing a challenge of building a new field that meets major league quality in an existing venue that wasn't designed to hold a regulation field.\"\n\nSo the first order of business was to excavate and remove the top two feet of the playing surface.\n\nA system of pipes was installed that could drain away rainwater at a rate of seven to 10 inches an hour. Above it, a layer of gravel was applied, then a blend of sand and dirt for the roots of the grass to grow into.\n\nThen bermuda-grass sod was meticulously rolled on top.\n\nCook's crew was also in charge of replacing the dugouts, the backstop, foul poles and the fencing around the field.\n\nBrightview also encountered two clashes of yesterday and today: The field needed netting all the way down the foul territory, very much unlike the screens of decades ago; and the existing light standards actually protruded from the top of the roof over the field.\n\n\"Those lights are part of the charm and history there, and we didn't want to take them down,\" Cooks says. \"We left the fixtures and took out the lenses and bulbs, so if a ball did hit them, you wouldn't have glass crashing onto a player.\"\n\nThe lighting for the MLB night game will come from temporary light standards, brought in on flatbed trucks.\n\n\"The big challenge with Rickwood was to ensure we maintained the magic and history of the venue,\" says Cook.\n\nIn recent years, MLB has staged events in venues where none had existed previously. Examples include the pop-up ballpark built on an abandoned golf course at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in 2016 and the incredibly successful Field of Dreams games in the cornfield in Dyersville, Iowa, the past two years.\n\nRickwood Field presents unique challenges.\n\n\"We were handed a stadium that is very old and doesn't meet code in many ways,\" says Todd Barnes, principal at architecture firm Populous. \"We had to fit Major League Baseball into a place that was never intended to have it.\"\n\nThe park's tiny locker rooms and press box didn't come close to doing the job.\n\n\"Rickwood was never built in scale for any occupancy of this size,\" says Populous associate principal Michael Kinard. \"We have to provide almost all the facilities that are required for the event, from clubhouses to the operational area to media functions.\"\n\nWhat little parking had been adjacent to Rickwood is now occupied by a complex of temporary structures housing all of the functions needed to host a modern-day MLB contest. Fans will have to park at Legion Field a mile away and take shuttles to the ballpark.\n\n\"The goal was to take a very gentle touch to it,\" says Barnes. \"Obviously, we didn't want to overhaul a historic building.\"\n\nNo new structures were added. Instead, existing seats were removed to accommodate wheelchairs.\n\n\"We love these kinds of challenges and accept them with open arms. These are the best games for us overall,\" says Barnes. \"We're creating the pallet for MLB to frame the right game presentation to make it just an incredible day.\"\n\nJoe Mock covers sports facilities for USA TODAY publications", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballpark", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ballpark"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Major League Baseball"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobb_County,_Georgia", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Cobb County, Georgia"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Cobb County, Georgia"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friends", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Friends"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395958846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:19:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:19:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:17:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2024/06/the-opener-rickwood-field-abrams-toro.html", "title": "The Opener: Rickwood Field, Abrams, Toro", "body": "As the 2024 regular season continues, here are three things we'll be keeping an eye on around the baseball world throughout the day today:\n\n1. MLB at Rickwood Field to Honor Willie Mays:\n\nThe Giants and Cardinals are set to face off this evening in a game at Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Alabama scheduled for 6:15pm local time. The game, which will be televised nationally on FOX, was initially scheduled as a tribute to the Negro Leagues and their storied history but has taken on additional meaning after the recent passing of MLB legend Willie Mays earlier this week. Mays briefly played a professional in the Negro Leagues during the 1948 season as a member of the Birmingham Black Barons, appearing in 13 games for the club as a 17-year-old in the midst of a season where the Black Barons went on to capture the NAL pennant before losing the final Negro League World Series to the Homestead Grays in five games.\n\nThe Black Barons (and, by extension, Mays) called Rickwood Field their home ballpark. First established in 1910, it's the oldest professional ballpark in the US and two years older than Fenway Park in Boston. More than 75 years after the last Negro League game was played there, Major League play returns to Rickwood Field tonight as St. Louis and San Francisco face off with right-handed youngsters Andre Pallante and Keaton Winn on the mound. Tonight's game will (as relayed by The Athletic's Ken Rosenthal) feature the first entirely black crew of umpires in AL/NL history and figures to celebrate not only the storied history of the Negro Leagues, but also the life and career of Mays.\n\n2. Abrams to undergo MRI:\n\nNationals shortstop CJ Abrams was scratched from yesterday's lineup against the Diamondbacks due to what manager Davey Martinez told reporters (including those at MLB.com) was being termed discomfort in his left wrist. Martinez went on to add that Abrams wasn't sure what was causing the discomfort, and that the club planned to send their young star for an MRI to ensure all was well. The 23-year-old Abrams has enjoyed a breakout season with the Nationals this year as he's slashed an impressive .261/.313/.478 with 10 stolen bases and 11 home runs in 66 games this year. That strong slash line comes in spite of a difficult month of May where Abrams hit just .205/.216/.304 in 27 games.\n\nAbrams's breakout campaign has helped the Nationals to be surprisingly competitive this season, as the club is currently tied with the Cardinals for the second of three NL Wild Card spots despite a lackluster 36-37 record. A significant stretch of time without Abrams would be a brutal blow to the Nationals' odds of holding onto that position, as his 1.2 fWAR leads the club's positional corps. Nasim Nunez took over for Abrams at shortstop yesterday and could be the club's top option to fill in if Abrams requires a trip to the injured list.\n\n3. Toro battling shoulder soreness:\n\nA's infielder Abraham Toro is dealing with a bout of shoulder soreness, as noted by MLB.com's Martin Gallegos yesterday. The issue first cropped up during Oakland's doubleheader against the Twins on Sunday and has caused him to miss each of the past two games. As relayed by Gallegos, Toro was scheduled to meet with team doctors to discuss how to handle the injury but manager Mark Kotsay told reporters after the game that he had no update on Toro's status and that more information about the infielder would be available today.\n\nToro, 27, has had a decent season with the A's this year. He's posted a roughly average slash line of .256/.298/381 in 71 games for the club this year while splitting time between first base, second base, third base, and left field throughout the year. In the aftermath of the club's decision to designate J.D. Davis for assignment earlier this week, it appeared likely that Toro would be handed the keys to third base full time, although with Toro now possibly injured, Oakland will have to find a new solution at the hot corner. Infielder Tyler Nevin has handled third base duties so far during Toro's absence and could be the club's long-term answer there if Toro misses further time, although rookie third baseman Brett Harris is also on the 40-man roster after getting a 17-game cup of coffee in the majors earlier this year.", "source": {"uri": "mlbtraderumors.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MLB Trade Rumors"}, He was dangerous in the batter's box, hitting 38 home runs and had a lifetime batting average of 317. He was fast too, stealing 49 bases.\n\nCobbin was looking forward to being part of the tribute, seeing other Negro League players, and welcoming the recognition from the commissioner and all of baseball.\n\n\"I think all the Negro League ballplayers received letters and invitations from the commissioner of Major League Baseball that's a great deal. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_Baseball", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Commissioner of Baseball"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "St. Louis Cardinals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham,_Alabama", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Birmingham, Alabama"}, "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Baseball"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 34}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Minor_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Minor League", "wgt": 26}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Negro_Leagues", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Negro Leagues", "wgt": 47}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "wgt": 28}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Women", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Women", "wgt": 25}], "image": "https://www.wkbn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/48/2024/06/jim-cobbin-negro-leagues-mlb.jpg?strip=1&w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9665999", "eventUri": "eng-9665999", "location":
